reviewText:
Okay. What i'm about to tell you actually ♥♥♥♥ing happened.

I joined an rp server with 15 people. At first i was confused, and went around being a general knob, stealing cars, sitting on people, ect. Somehow i didnt get banned for fail RP. After about an hour of observing these people mingle around, I decided to join in. I sat with them as they put some dude on trial for some reason. Then, everyone got in a treehouse and there was lava and blah blah blah it was interesting, but this isnt the best part. So, after this, everyone started to properly RP. People went to their houses, got their cars, ect. Intrigued by this, I decided to stalk an unsuspecting household and observe everyday life in Blockland. Soon enough, they relised i was watching them, and they dubbed me 'the stalker under the porch' and 'the creepy guy by the window'. I stood around, holding a bunny doll and staring motionlessly in at them. After a while, I managed to get into their house. I stayed low, and snuck around, eating their pizza. Soon enough though, they found me. I retreated into a corner, under their stairs. And they locked me in. Kept me as their pet. I couldnt escape, i couldnt move, i couldnt run. But they fed me and talked to me, and I gave up hope on ever getting out. After a while they got bored and buggered off (they let me out after some persuasion though). After another hour of building my own ♥♥♥♥♥♥ yellow house, i returned to their house, and they welcomed me in this time. They let me use their toilet, watch tv, and partay all night. Some rocket launcher spammers came along but they were soon banned, and the partay carried on. At one point, they embedded me into some concrete like Han Solo in Star Wars. But they let me out eventually. They were cool people, and thats rare to find in a game. And then, some guy came along and told me to follow him. So i followed him, and he led me to his house. He told me to be a baby.  I was confused at first, but then he locked the doors, somehow shrunk me, and made me crawl around, typing baby noises in chat, and chilling in a crib he made. It was ♥♥♥♥ing scary. And i really couldnt escape. After a while he took me to town in his car. I could only crawl around the place, so i happily accepted the transport away from that guys creepy ♥♥♥ house. Now i just needed to lose this guy (without failing rp). The guy crashed the car, and i snuck off, claiming i was a scared and confused baby. Thats where everything went to ♥♥♥♥. I engaged operation 'Grand Theft Baby', stole a car, a gun, and as my baby self, i hit the road. This pedo guy tried looking for me with his jetpack, but i hit the hills and quietly disconected from the game.

This was one ♥♥♥♥ing server. I spent 4 hours on 1 ♥♥♥♥ing server having the creepiest yet most fun time of my life. Not to mention the fact that i went insane from the fact that the house i was stalking had some wierd radio playing a song about tacos on repeat. (at one point it glitched out and amplified like 100 times; my ears bled...)

This was ONE ♥♥♥♥ing server. There are other great servers, such as the battlefield-esque dogfighting server, or the knife TDM server. This game is absolutley incredible. Not to mention the incredible options for creativity and modding in single player (addons galore!), and the wonderful destruction physics!

This game is a must have if you like RP, multiplayer games in general and creative games. Its incredible fun, i played 9 ♥♥♥♥ing hours on my first day of owning it. I love Blockland, and though it may be dying player wise, its still one hell of a time!

Its like Lego, Gmod and Roblox had a baby!

Oh yeah, and, for whatever ♥♥♥♥ing reason, you can get an achivment called 'gay pirate' for wearing a pink pirate hat. WTF!?

10/10 IGN

No seriously, like 8/10 (its buggy, its dying, but as i said, its a hell of a time!)

UPDATE 28-04-2014

So I haven't been very active within Blockland and only recently I've learned that Return to Blockland has been shutdown since February. Well, bugger. One of the biggest things on this review was RTB's existence.

Not to worry! The community has already found ways to circumvent its shutdown and there are backup pages and a whole new chat addon thingy that imitates RTB's.

reviewText:
Abandoned by a careless developer

First:
Don't be fooled by the game's trailer. Blockland isn't a lego universe full of fun things to do and intresting people to meet. This game is a trap. I have been playing it since it's earliest days (I was literally one of the first hundred people to buy this game). It was fun at the start when there was still clans and builds and gamemodes were still new and exciting. But it hasn't risen with the times.

Nothing new has really been made since 2010. It WAS a very fun game to play, when there was still new things being made and that could be discovered. But nothing like that has happened for this game in a very long time. And with years the community deteroriated to become what it now is today. And the patehtic community of this game only more so worsens it's already near-broken state.

Blockland is only kept up and running so Eric can leach more money off it. Little has he done to update it or improve it in any way for a long time. And guess what, he doesn't care. He's literally said multiple times that the only reason he is still giving Blockland even a fraction of his time or effort is because it makes him too much money for him to stop. And when I say a fraction... I truly mean even less than that. He has done nothing and put virtually no effort into improving the game or updating it in any way that the players or the community would appreciate.

The game is NOTHING like it is in the trailer. Sure a lot of that stuff shown in the trailer is possible but I can personally garuntee that not a single server being hosted at this time has anything even close to that exciting or unique.

The community for this game is virtually nonexistant (unless you're dying to be in a commuinty full of autocratic ♥♥♥♥♥). I have not seen a gaming community full of more hostile and irrational people in my life. This is why all of our servers have nothing good.

People on the forums site are pathetic. They do absolutely nothing to upkeep the game or make it better in any way, and spend virtually all of their time ranting on about how the community sucks and making drama threads pointing fingers at users when in reality EVERYONE on the site is doing the exact same thing for the game: NOTHING. Which is why it sucks! :)


No, you won't be doing anything like what's in that trailer. Hate to break it to you. Unless you want to spend days learning how to make all of those things yourself and submerge yourself in a community full up stuck up arrogant ♥♥♥♥♥♥, don't buy this game.

reviewText:
The developer has finally admitted that he has stopped all development[forum.blockland.us] on the game, as if it hadn't been already obvious considering the lack of updates in the past ten months, the half-broken Steam version of the game (broken for a year already), and the extremely low quality and quantity of the updates before then. He has resorted to censoring and banning people who criticize the game's development[blocklandcloud.com], so this should be an obvious sign that the game is done for. When or if you buy this abandoned game, consider the fact that this disrespectful, uncaring and greedy developer" will be getting your money.

Original review:

I have played this game for more than 5 years (not on Steam) and I am disappointed at how quickly it has declined. Don't be fooled into buying this game just because it looks great. The developers (developer) have abandoned the game. Check out my long elaboration on why I think the game is practically abandoned:
http://www.reddit.com/r/BlocklandIsHorrible/comments/267v7h/badspot_is_no_longer_doing_his_fair_share_of_work/

The game hasn't had a major update for 2 years and any update for 6 months. The game's most important people have been angry about the developer's ("Badspot") reluctance to maintain the game's development. Check out this satirical comic which illustrates the developer's greed: http://brockrandcomics.tumblr.com/post/92596058472/filipe-7-22-14

CLARIFICATION FOR BELOW PARAGRAPH: server hosting issues do not include those who have bought the game in the classical way and duplicated their purchases to their Steam accounts

column31:
you can't play the game at the same time. Want someone else to circumvent these restrictions by hosting a server for you under your name? Too bad; hosting services cannot be used by people who bought the game through Steam. The developers have neglected Steam users and deprived them of server hosting for over 6 months. I think it's clear that they do not care anymore and are only trying to make a quick buck out of what the game has left.

reviewText:
I've probably put over 1500 hours into this before it came to steam.
This is one of the best games I have ever played. It's limitlessly open, with a great mature (edit 4 months later: kind of mature, it's a lego game, of course it'll attract kids.) community, and there's just so much to experience, from dogfights, to city RPGs, to gangster shootouts, to go-kart races, to who-knows-what! There's thousands upon thousands of addons (plugins/mods) for the game that are extremely easy to install and the game is still going strong since it's initial build in 2004!
Buy this game!
Buy it!
Buy it now!

reviewText:
[If you dislike reading seemingly irrelevant information you are free to skip to the bottom of this review. There you will find my recommendation. Thank you!]

So this game has been one of my favorite building games of all time. Starting in 2010 along with the majority of what I would say was our community, I bought the original Blockland and was having a great time. Things were getting done, updates being made. There were these classics maps I'll never forget: the Bedroom, the Kitchen, and the Slopes. I enjoyed this game, and I was estimated to be playing it about 10 hours a day or more. (Update: Many people don't believe I played this game as long as I claim. The truth is, Blockland existed before (its release on) Steam. For this reason, Steam has not registered all my hours from when I played it before. I only recently migrated to Steam Blockland from the original Vanilla Blockland. Hope that clears things up!)

It took some time but an insightful man by the name of Ephialtes in-game decided to build Blockland a new system. I believe it was around 2011-2012 that this became widely-used. It was called Return to Blockland, and was basically the Steam client for Blockland before Blockland was actually on Steam. It had a 'Workshop' (servers that hosted add-ons you could directly download from), Add-On Manager, Friends client, global IRC chat, chat rooms, easy-to-use settings system for your server, add-on preferences manager, and so much more. It was the true revelation of Blockland's existence. It brought upon a new experience for the Blockland community, and gave it a modern feel.

Then this game went on Greenlight.

That officially marked the downfall of RTB, which would eventually be shut down because Steam replaced 1/3 of its functionality. There would no longer be a place to manage your add-ons, chat globally with other BL users, find your friends (since they would no longer be on RTB and you didn't know if they had Steam), and last but not least, you could no longer manage your server like you used to.

That probably drove me away the most. I stuck around for a bit, hosted a multitude of mildly popular servers as well as a 32/32 player MERP server that consisted of most of my time. After about four months, I kinda lost interest and began the process of leaving the BL community. I left a legacy, but even that would soon be forgotten...

So you know that game called Minecraft? I ended up spending almost all of my time on that. I hosted some very popular servers on Minecraft, met some great friends, and was enjoying it. I almost forgot about Blockland completely, but then my friend (who shall remain nameless) decided to get Blockland after I showed him a fun little gamemode on it called Renderman. He got it, and when I saw that he did, I decided to hop back on and play with him... but I didn't do much otherwise.

I truly came back about two months ago. I began hosting my MERP server, probably just to feel the nostalgia and see all the empires that had been built on it. A friend of mine by the name of Amir (a full-time player of my server back when it was popular) happened to stop by. We had an awesome reunion, played a bit of MERP (not really. Just remarked on how sucky our builds were), had a lot of fun. I began playing Blockland much more.

And then I stopped. Garry's Mod took up my time. I managed a community on there and couldn't depart from them. But that wasn't the only reason.

I lost interest.

So anyways, if you got to the bottom of this review reading through an incredibly long backstory and wondering why the heck I'd write a story like that, I congratulate you. You have the patience of a... you, but none of this was really a review, was it?

So here's my take on the game.

If you want to play a game with a large amount of active community supporters/respectful, mature players, don't get this game.

If you want to play a game where you build anything and can do anything (with the help of a bit of programming knowledge or the visually-based event system), get this game.

If you want to play a game where servers are always full and there is an easy way to liven up your game with user-created add-ons, don't get this game.

If you want to play a game where you can host a server of any kind, have some fun with Pirate Ship DM gamemodes, and basically shoot your friends with laser pistols and horse rays (yeah, they turn them into a horse), this game IS FOR YOU.

BUT. If you want a game that will keep you interested for years to come, always ready for that next update, always ready for that next big thing... don't get this game. It's unkempt, uncombed, and unfathomably stagnate.

But I might be wrong. What if YOU are the next big thing?

In my opinion, this game is NOT recommended due to the lack of interesting things that may be found in Blockland. It's a great game, don't get me wrong, but it is running on steam (get it hahahahaaha... haha. ..ha... sorry) and no longer has that spark of a game that has true potential. Maybe Badspot can turn this around one day. And maybe you can be a part of that. Me, on the other hand, have exhausted the game of Blockland. I like the game, but I can no longer play it.

Maybe it'll be different for you.

reviewText: I'll admit it. I played ROBLOX when I got my computer back in 2010. Was ROBLOX awful? Yes. They turned a simple lego creativity game into a pay to play kind of game. Blockland, however, is not. Blockland uses all of the elements that ROBLOX has and multiplies the options by ten, with more controls, bricks, and ways to play. If you were to buy a Garry's Mod lego set, that would be Blockland. Lots of servers to choose from, many gamemodes (Even custom ones!), a community that is suprisingly adult-aged, and hours of fun. I would recommend this to anyone who loves LEGO's and Garry's Mod.

reviewText:
The vanilla game may not have a ton to offer, so it all comes down to what the community has to offer (which is a ton). The gameplay makes it a lot like Gmod, except with a more consistant style. Additionally, it's multiplayer architecture makes joining servers with custom content seamless. You'll literally never need to actually install an add-on to play on a server with custom content (with a few exceptions, servers using custom GUI's may want you to install their GUI mods in order to play. This is usually optional anyways.)

The gamemode system adds a lot more 'out of the box' fun things to do than the game used to have. But it's still a bit underwhelming and you'll probably only get about a few hours of fun out of it if you refuse to install any add-on gamemodes or other things. Other than a few gamemodes available that are designed to be played in single-player, multiplayer is really where everything is at. There are a number of servers that have been developed for literally years and have a very high quality experience. If you ever really enjoyed Gmod at all, you'll probably find that the most fun servers in Blockland are ones where someone has simply set out a blank slate and a bunch of really neat mods. Shenanigans ensue.

It's a game you'll just keep coming back to.

reviewText: The first online game I ever played. Don't let my measly 120 hours fool you; before this got on Steam, I'd spend so many days after school just playing this, messing around with friends and creating memories that genuinely fill me with tears of joy as I think back on them today.\n\nSince I started back in 2009, I've been building, shooting, making videos, mining, and just generally messing around with the multitudes of crazy add-ons that have made the game what it is today. It's definitely not as alive as it used to be, but for what it is now, it's well worth ten bucks. I paid 20 bucks for it and it basically got me to where I am today, shaping my interests and online presence. I've certainly had a blast.

reviewText:
The game is about building anything you can imagine, it's a non-linear sandbox game in which the world is your canvas. Literally a blank canvas.

I've played this game since it was in vers. 8. I had the time of my life playing on all the deathmatch and freebuild servers and whatnot.

When I discovered addons and mods, I was amazed. People made all sorts of new vehicles, bricks, weapons etc. for the game. I decided I'd download some and try them out.

The one addon/mod I really enjoyed was Gamemode_Zombie. It was a L4D-style addon with all the zombie types (boomer, hunter, etc.) There was even a subway map made for it.

Now, there was this sort of client within the game called Return to Blockland (RTB). It included a friends list and an addon manager and even a public chat thing where you could talk to anyone that had RTB. It was overall just a neat way to chat with friends and find new addons.

But the game has taken a turn for the worse, I am afraid. Not too long ago, RTB was shut down. The friend system was no longer available and the mod downloader/manager was shut down as well. It was much harder to contact friends and see what addons were installed on your game. This made many people upset and the game just sort of died.

The game itself, though, had a decent amount of content. There were maps such as Kitchen, The Slopes, and Bedroom that you could explore. Now, these maps weren't made of bricks so that's what made them unique.

The V21 update changed this. Maps were replaced by nicer graphics and better shaders,
and to make up for the loss of maps we were given an empty slate to build on. The ground and skybox were, or /are/ customizeable with different textures and whatnot.

The loss of RTB and the maps has just led to the downfall of this game. The community has turned in to some sort of mix of a Tumblr/♥♥♥♥♥ drama-fest full of feels and oppression where everyone thinks they can flame and argue with each other to solve their problems.

I haven't played this game for about 2-3 months because there just isn't anything new or exciting to see and do and, as i stated in the previous paragraph, the community is just downright bad. The servers are low-quality with 99.9% of them being horrid Five Nights at Freddy's RPs and that last .1% being an actual good server with decent admins and choice of addons. (which honestly is hard to find, you should be happy if you actually manage to find or make one.)

I can't exactly recommend this game. Once it gets better (which it clearly never will), then maybe I'll change my review.

maybe.

I give this game a 3/10.

TL;DR
------

-The game was good up until v21.

-Maps were awesome and now we just have a blank slate.

-There was a good community with a good amount of content.

-RTB closed down and everything went bad, especially the community.

-FNAF fanboys.

-tumblr party

-RIP, Blockland.

-3/10

sorry for the novel of a review.

Now, this is a review all about how
My gaming life got flipped-turned upside down

In Slopes and Bedroom born and raised
On singleplayer was where I spent most of my days
Loadin' saves on maps, relaxin' all cool
And planting some bricks just like a noob
When a couple of players who were up to no good
Started making trouble in my server

I begged and pleaded with him day after day

I was finally there
To sit on my throne as the Prince of Blockland

reviewText: After all my hours into Blockland, I can't recommend it. The Blockland community has to be one of the most toxic communities I've ever experienced in any video game, and that's saying something because I've played L4D2. The sheer amount of players who think they're better than others because they browse the forums is way too much. This also applies to the braindead five nights at freddys fanboys or undertale groupies. The creator Badspot (Eric Hartman) rarley ever updates his game. Infact I don't think there has been a single major update since I've started playing, I think there was one and that was a bug fix or something. He's very active on the forums and everyone practically worships him. The forums are another issue, pure cancer. People there are so egotistical it's not even funny, constantly circle jerking each other on the stupiest ♥♥♥♥. Blockland has served me well and I've met many good friends from it but it has gotten way too bad for me. If you're going to buy this game then be prepared.\n\nSorry if this sounded too hostile, I'm not a very hostile person. This review was more of a rant about present day Blockland. If Blockland somehow changes and Badspot starts updating his game again I'll come back but until then I can't see myself playing it anymore.

reviewText: I played this game back when it wasn't on Steam, I was one of those annoying five-years-olds who destroyed other people's stuff. I had a one month membership on this game, and I played it non-stop (most likely over 200 hours total) for the short time I had it. After I ran out of the membership, I went to Roblox (bad idea, big war going on between Blockland and Roblox at that time). After I quit Roblox, I went to Minecraft. Then I (semi)quit Minecraft and went to Steam. After about two years on Steam, I found this game. I had wonderful flashbacks of how me and my cousin would destroy everything, and build it again, then destroy it, again and again and again. My previously mentioned cousin actually bought this game for me (props to you, my friend!) on steam and we played. Although a lot changed, almost to the point where I couldn't recognize it, I still had fun. The new maps were fun, the old maps were still fun, and the whole game had been transformed into a world of small communities and close friends. This is one of my favorite games right now, and I recommend it for my own story, but you should buy this game so you can make your own story, and in a few years, when you are a pro at Blockland, look back at this review and make your own. I know that sounds really cheesy, but seriously, we need to have fun with our games and tell the amazing times and adventures that we have in those games to show people why they should create their own. So, buy this game, right now. Make your own story. Make your own review. Do what I have done, tell others to do so. This is the perfect game for it, so much to do, so much to see. So, what are you waiting for, do it!

reviewText: Blockland used to be one of my Favourite games, There were fun map with hidden secrets, The bedroom, The slopes and The kitchen, and you could always get add-ons with  RTB (Return to blockland), an amazing site for finding cool mods. However, Things changed.\nFirst of all, Actual maps were removed and only a flat baseplate was left standing. Although there's still structures that you can load up, they're simply no-where near as good as the original maps. This Meant that MP servers were now boring, as most modded gamemodes can't be played. I won't say that the community was ever perfect, it used to be good, but now RTB is abandoned and Blockland servers are basically empty shells of what they used to be. There's also the fact that the blocks that can be used to build are practically LEGO Blocks, which means that even building simple square houses is a tedious process. Overall, Blockland is a true gem lost in time, what used to be a thriving gaming community has become a desolate wasteland and has fallen prey to Money-Hog Developers that can't be bothered to fix their already ruined game.\n3/10 would not have One of my favourite games ruined again.

reviewText:
This game is a good game IF: You put in the time to learn it.  I have put about 5 months into this game outside of steam, and I still love it.  I feel like I can get more out of it the more I play it.

I am going to address most of the things the negative reviews are saying about this game.

1.  Minecraft is better

In this game it is hard to build things that look good, but you can make things in much greater detail than in minecraft.  The building in this game is superior to minecraft's building.  You can build things with dozens of different bricks (not including brick mods) unlike minecraft that just has a standard block with different textures and a few other detail blocks like fences.  Minecraft has a terrible combat system that makes it awful for mini games.  This game has amazing combat elements.  You can do anything in this game in minecraft, but not nearly as well or easily.  Minecraft combat and minigames feel cheap and not very well put together.  I personally hate minecraft, but that does not make it a bad game.     It is a good survival sandbox game, but it ends there.  Anything above that can be done better in so many other games.

2.  The developer is awful

Who cares, you are buying the game not the developer.  If you are not on the forums and arn't stealing anyones keys or doing something that would get you banned from any other multiplayer game on steam, you will be fine.  I have never had a problem with the developer at any time.

3.  The community is awful

I really have not noticed this outside of the forums, and even so, it is mostly the drama section of the forums that is awful.  It depends on the server you go on of course, but the whole community is not awful.  The bad community in this game consists of the ones that keep complaining about how terrible the developer and community is.  I don't see them doing anything to make it better, they just tick off the developer with their constant complaining which I find makes me angry as well.  I don't even deal with a hundreth as much as the developer does, so excuse him for for being cranky sometimes.

If you look for terrible people in a community you will find terrible people in a community.  If you look for awesome people in a community you will find awesome people in a community.

4.  Not enough content/game is dying

Not true.  Since this game has been on steam only over a year at the time of this review, the community has more than trippled.  Dying? ok sure.  More people means more mods and servers.  Mods are so easy to install in this game, and it is the only game that I do not find it to be a hassel to do so.  People have modded the game so heavily that it does not even feel like the same game anymore.  This game is fairly dependant on mods, but it has some VERY good mods.

5.  Terrain/interriors replaced with shaders and it ruined the game

Terrain and interriors were not all that great.  Like really they were ok for a few servers, but I only used the flat maps and built my own terrain.  They simply were not easy to build on in many cases which happens to be one of the main points of the game.  The shadows and shaders look amazing and are also moddable.  Even if you cannot run them, it does not take away from the game.  There is an environment editing GUI that allows you to edit the lighting, weather, fog, ground texture/color, water level, and other things.  One of the most used maps before the removal of terrain was adjustable plate which was the same thing as the environment edit GUI but not as good.

And finally...

This game is great if you put the time in to learn it and have friends to play with.  Most of the time I have put into this game I have played without friends, so they are not required to have fun.  There are times when there are not many interesting servers to join, but even then you can just host your own.  Don't listen to those complaining about the community and the dev.  If you like building and or a casual FPS I would highly recommend this game.  There have been times when I did not build for months playing this game, and I just enjoyed the fighting/shooter servers.

reviewText:
Played since 2007, even before the Steam Greenlight migration happened. Basically, I grew up with this game. I met some good friends in the community. It was good. I'm not sure up until now since the new visual features were added, but still a good game in its core. I've spent a ♥♥♥♥♥on of hours on this game ever since. Now, I think I've grown up from this game, but I think new people can appreciate it as well.

RTB (Return to Blockland) was game's greatest community mod API ever. Unfortunately, it was shut down by its creator Ephialtes, due to a majority of its functionality was overrun by Steam's community tools. It's sad, because a majority of good, curated add-ons were on its database. I just hope Badspot (the developer) finds a way to introduce the Steam Workshop to Blockland in order to compensate this.

The downside to add-ons recently is that all add-ons are not curated anymore, just scanned for malicious or too-crappy code/content. Nonetheless, some high quality add-ons still exist in the community forums.

Disclaimer though,A high percentage of the community is difficult to manage with (considering most are kids at the moment). This can be avoided if you have a lot of patience in communicating with children.

Again, due to the most of the community being children, banning was a common act of the developer. There were as well, older people who are apparently trolls who love to spark the fire in the community. Some are it for fun, while some are it for revenge. This is the reason why some people are angry at the developer for cleansing the community of many people.

Only a fraction are those excellent to play with and communicate with. Occasionally, you will find a fraction of this community on some servers.

Even though there is no Workshop, mods are pretty easy to download, but since Return to Blockland was discontinued they are a bit harder to get to work. Overall, I'd recommend it with a 7.5/10

reviewText:
Ok, before you start dissing me on this, let me just say a few things:

1. Just because RTB's service was shutdown, it does NOT mean the game is ruined. You can still get addons off of mirrors, and some addons even have a new IRC/addons manager. You can even still use the old RTB client for managing your addons as well, just not downloading them.

2. Badspot is not saying the community is the problem. He is saying that it is a specific age group, and he can not control all of them. They host their own servers, with their own rules. Don't get mad if one of them happens to ban you for acting annoying to them or others, or you don't read their rules.

3. When you think of the community, you're probably thinking of the forums. Let me just say, that you're probably browsing the Off-Topic section and just saying that's not normal. Please note, you are looking in the OFF-TOPIC section. Most Blockland related things are in the Blockland, Files, and Modification Help sections.

Alright, now to the review.

This game is a load of fun, mainly because you can honestly do whatever you want. You can build a house, make a sprite from a game in blocks, have a deathmatch with some friends, it's almost ALL customizable.

There's also addons you can download to add new blocks, events, weapons, tools, and other things to the game. A example of a new way to play is Unlimited Mining, which is exactly what it says on the tin: Mining that can stretch forever. It may seem boring, but it's not just the same ores. The deeper you dig, the closer you get to the Core, which has more valuable and radiated ores. and then, there's the secret area above grounds, that's very difficult to find...

The multiplayer's fun as well, you just need to be careful on what servers you go on, and read their rules carefully. Some people don't seem to get this, and end up joining random servers, get banned, and get all flustered wondering what they did wrong. People have their own rules, and others might not want you on your server.

And finally, there's the downtime. Normally, this isn't our fault. It's a problem with a few other people, like BDX, or Man of Reason, DDoSing the server when they feel like it, causing the master server and forums to go down. The master server is how you are able to see the server list. If that's down, you probably won't be able to join any servers.

Even though this game may seem off due to bad reviews, this game is what helped me finally play with others and have some fun. It was fun in 2008, and it's fun now. Try buying it while it's on sale, when it ever does, so you can spend less to try it. Even better, you can download the demo here: http://blockland.us/Download.html

You'll have to buy the game in order to play past the block limit, but trust me, it's much better when you're not limited.

reviewText:
I love this game.
No, let me rephrase that.
I loveD this game.

This game used to be great. There were many custom maps to explore, and lots of community gamemodes to play. There was always a lot of people to play with and the community was generally awesome. Did you notice any thing about those last sentences? One; Everything I listed was community-made. The developer's actual content is not very interesting to play with for more than a few hours. Two; It was past tense. Maps were actually REMOVED from the game for no good reason and a good portion of the community left due to that. And then RTB stopped. RTB, or Return to Blockland, was a mod for Blockland which worked as a mod manager and also friends list. RTB was awesome and was the only thing anyone used to keep track of friends and get mods. And then, one day, RTB was gone. The servers were down and you couldn't download it anymore. That caused a large portion of to leave the game and now we're left with the remains of a once amazing game, barely managing to keep enough players.

You could buy this game as it is. I wouldn't blame you. This game is still good, if only for a day or two. But if you do buy this, I recommend this to go along with it: https://github.com/portify/blockland-20
DISCLAIMER: You cannot use this without owning Blockland, and even if you could, I would not endorse doing so without a purchase. If you run a server on the main master server of Blockland using this version, your account may be terminated.

reviewText:
PROS:

-Graphics: Graphics are quite nice. The bricks are very accurate to real life. Plus there are shaders.

-Eventing: You can program your bricks to appear/disappear, shoot a rocket, or you could build an entire computer!

-Bots: Comes with fully programmable bots. You can make them kill you, or fight for you.

CONS:

-Addons: You needs loads of addons to do anything really cool, or to get people to join your server.

-RTB: Return to Blockland was a great addon system with advanced features and IRC, and it no longer exists.

-Eventing: The event interface is nice for beginners, but once you start making more complex things, it becomes quite cumbersome.

-Lack of updates: The developer is inactive most of the time. Don't expect anything more to come out of this.

-Vehicle physics: Vehicles glitch through walls/floor, especially flying ones.

-Controls: Sometimes they are quite hard for beginners to learn, mostly building. If you don't have a number pad, this can become quite difficult.

Yep, that's my take on the game. It really has the potential; but it just wasn't executed right.

reviewText:
The game is very fun and interesting, and building in a lego world has endless possibilities. The game also has a lot of add-ons and modifications.
However, the worst part of Blockland is the community. Just go to http://forum.blockland.us and see how horrible it is for youself. It's basically a group of users who argue a lot and spend more time on the forums than playing the actual game.

Development is also deteriorating. Version 21, which was released in August 2012, was the last major update to the game. It was supposed to make it easier to add more features in the future, but a major update has not been released yet. Blockland also uses a 15-year-old game engine and this causes a lot of problems for add-on makers, such as glitchy vehicle physics and limitations on projectile speed.
In conclusion: great gameplay and originality, but horrible community and slow development.

EDIT: Yesterday, Heedicalking, a notable member of the Blockland community peacefully protested against the lack of the new features (which were promised exactly 2 years ago). Badspot, the owner of the game, deleted his posts and banned him on three accounts: https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/54466069/banned.png

reviewText:
Although I do still find the game entertaining from time to time, I would not recommend it now for other users. Here are the reasons why:
The in-game servers and content don't have the same variety or atmosphere as they had when I first bought the game 3 or 4 years ago. Although that could just be nostalgia talking, that is, of course, something that drastically affects my relationship and experience with the game.
The engine isn't at all the best (After all, it's more than a decade old. To be more frank, the game engine is virtually ancient.), which puts some signifcant limitations on modders, despite the admittedly incredulous amount of flexibility and ease of the add-on system.
Although there are some good-looking shaders, they are not well-optimised, and were put into the game hastily at the cost of the mapping system that the game had, at the dismay of many players.
The creator of the game, Badspot, has shown little to no interest in actively participating in enriching Blockland's community and playability, and although he does argue that the players are very much capable of expanding the enjoyment of the game, the players alone are not as impactful as an update from the creator of the game that would allow more capacity to do what you want with the game, regardless of the level of quality and initiative of the said community at hand.Although that's all I could think of right now, I will add more of my gripes and arguments about this game in later edits, and maybe even possibly completely rewrite this review. Like I said earlier, it's not as fun and filled with variety in user-generated content as it was before, which could very well say something about the community. I have been playing far before the game even was greenlighted on Steam, and have witnessed the transformation of this game overtime. If the developer of the game or other members of the community would like to talk to me about this review, or perhaps get feedback from me on my opinion on how to improve the game, you are more than welcome to. Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
I think this game has gone downhill for a while. I remember when I first played it in 2010 and it was pretty decent I guess. There was a good stream of updates now and then and the game was actually enjoyable. But now I have no idea where it's gone to. The community of the game really drags it down for me, and since this game is almost 90% based on multiplayer, it might affect you too. The community is not forgiving at all so if you do something wrong/bad you will still be bashed for it years later. The community loves to accuse you of doing things that you never did, such as conducting a denial of service attack. Nowadays, the creator barely pushes out updates and there hasn't been any meaningful updates for what seems to be an eternity. The creator of the game also is censoring people's negative reviews and banning them from discussions for peacefully expressing their opinions both on Steam and the Blockland Forums (by the way, if you're going to play the game, never join the Blockland Forums for sure. I can't tell you how screwed up that place is).

The game is, from time to time, enjoyable when you find a good server that is fun and has no hostile/bashing people on it. But otherwise I think this game has really gotten worse since my first purchase of it in 2010.

You choose if you want the game and are willing to completely ignore the community. I don't suggest you play it if you want to play on multiplayer a lot. The community is small and everybody can quickly know who you are and attack you for the rest of your stay if you screw up a few times.

Also there's the screw-up recurrence" game. You screw up and you know what you did was dumb. But the community keeps attacking you so you intentionally fight back and then at that point you're marked as a "problem user" and immediately banned from all game discussions. So if you like to express your opinions without censorship regarding the game
date:
this is not the place to do it.

Yeah my review will probably be censored since i'm marked as a "problem" user but what can I say?

You choose if you can ignore a hostile/corrupted/censoring community and creator where people actually think you can mark an "opinion" as wrong. If you can

reviewText:
The game was good for its time but there are better things available now. I wouldn't reccomend picking up Blockland as the developer has essentially stopped working on the product.


Minecraft is a much more adventure-based sandbox game with a lively modding community and is suitable for younger players (including children), but doesn't lose its appeal on adults.

Space Engineers is (as of writing) an early access game for building your own space craft. Its building system feels like Blockland, but it's backed by a very cool physics engine. More suitable for older players and adults, especially if you're interested in realism and engineering based sandbox games.

Blockland was a game I played for quite some time, but it hasn't aged well and has been usurped by newer and better things.

reviewText: One of the best games I've ever played, personally. The community is horrible at times, and extremely helpful at others. I started the game a while ago, then stopped playing it for a bit (I got bored of it). Then, I came back a year later, seeing no maps, and got slightly angry for a few days, and then got over it to see what it'd become. Bad, good, decent, hilarious, pathetic; Those were all going through my head as I relearned Blockland, although this time, I learned something new - Events. Eventing in Blockland is personally my favorite part (followed closely by the capability of them, and what you can make out of them). I still have a weekly rage session, just because some stupid thing happened in-game, but I don't mind. It's still among my favorite games. (Although something I don't like is the amount of roleplay in the game - specifically FNAF roleplay...)

reviewText:
Well... It's interesting.

I can see some people's issues with there not being enough parts, but the fact that you can make (or download) parts and toss them into an Add-Ons folder kinda gets rid of that complaint.  I think the biggest failing is the fact that the tutorial is REALLY basic, expecially where the wrench is concerned.  This game looks to be extremely powerful, but withot utilizing that power it's kind of like Superman having to remain Clark Kent because the world is made of Kryptonite.

Now, that aside, I'm seeing a pretty nice game here.  The block selection is done fairly well, allowing you to customize your quick-bars to whatever parts you wish to use.  In addition you use the mouse to begin placement of a block, but then use the numberpad to fine-tune that placement.  This is great in a 3D environment, as it truly gives you easy control of your building.  It even goes so far to, when placing something wrong, tell you exactly why the placement was rejected (overlapping, etc).  Finally, there are enough DEMO worlds in this game that you can truly see all of the possibilities you can get into (as long as you know how the wrench works).

When it all comes down to it, do I recommend people play this game?  Yes I do.  THAT SAID, continue reading...

I do recommend people play this game, however I only recommend BUYING the game if you can get it at a reduced price like I did.  I got this game as part of a $2.99 bundle on Bundle Stars, and for that price this game is well worth the money.  Would I pay $10+ for it?  Absolutely not, because it doesn't have a strong dev team behind it, the developer has a really bad attitude, and I doubt it'll ever be finished".

The most I'd ever pay is $2.99 for this game by itself...  That's a lot
date: considering I'm expecting the developer to see a lawsuit by Lego in the future."

reviewText:
I've grown up with Blockland for 5 years, and it has taught me a lot of things along it's pretty bumpy road. It's gotten me entirely into what I can call a 'lust for technology', because otherwise, I wouldn't be as interested in technology as a whole if it weren't for Blockland. Another thing is that, most everything I have learned or started to develop a skill about is also rounded about on Blockland, specificly, my sound designing 'expertise'. As a side note, I'm actually investing in sound recording equipment this christmas.

Blockland is not only largely based upon it's users to make content, much like Roblox or maybe even Minecraft, but it does a good job of making it easy to do so. I'm just barely starting off with being a content creator for the game yet I've already got the ropes, and I already create some good stuff for the game.

The community isn't as great as most lego games, but it's in a way, a 'mature' community. The community is incredibly assholish, especially on the forums, but in a way where most of the people won't go overboard over small things, and if you aren't a total idiot people won't try to kill you.

Lastly, I just wanna say, Blockland has many memories planting itself into my mind that I probably will never forget. The game holds so much promise for the future, and has always delivered in the past. People have doubted it before, even the community itself, but the game always keeps moving forward. Roblox, to compare, still retains it's immature community, it's pretty laggy systems, and it's really money-sucking notoriety for builders club.

reviewText:
This is easily one of my most played games of all time. You can pretty much do anything you want in this lego building environment, and in terms of it's building mechanics, you will find none better than Blockland. There is also an incredibly large amount of player-made resources and mods to expand the gameplay to pretty much anything you can think of. Stop playing games that limit you to building with one size blocks and play a game that truly gave many the best gaming experiences they've ever had.

Also while you're at that, check out my blockland videos on my Youtube channel!

youtube.com/sirherg1

reviewText:
Blockland is a sandbox game in LEGO style. BTW how did they manage the licence problem?
Blockland has a long history with an included social media platform and earlier IRC chats. I have heard of uncountable user maps that have exist. The hope is that on steam this project will be revived. There are several new game servers and now you're able to communicate over steam.
The graphics are average. For good example there's a fog of distance. But it is comfortable on the other side to play it just in window mode if you want. You can choose different game modes like car races or battle arena or free building. Blockland's strength is the huge library of existing models and build parts. It's easy to set spawn points for zombies or equip weapons to your character.
Tough there are other LEGO style or Minecraft style games out there, like Ace of Spades, but i think Blockland is a tryout worth.

reviewText:
Blockland has a bit of a history. In 2005, it was a little work-in-progress building game on the Torque Game Engine. Being an alpha, it had (here comes a massive understatement) quite a few mods that generated a larger following. The full game released in 2007, and much more polished than anything seen before. Streams of updates from the game's sole creator (with some collaboration thrown in) in the past six years have created a unique game that nothing can hope to come close to.

So, what's the main point? Blockland is That Game Where You Build Stuff. It's all on you, and the community. Using LEGO-like blocks to create structures in online multiplayer may sound mundane on paper, but the online part is where it really shines. The amount of creativity Blockland players have is nothing short of amazing. User-created add-ons like weapons and vehicles are plentiful, allowing for different and fun gamemodes within buildings YOU create, and an events" system gives way for even more creativity within builds.

An accessible sandbox game for such a price is almost a steal."

reviewText:
First and foremost, this is NOT another minecraft game

Blockland is a Garry's mod meet Legos meets [Insert anything here]
Like garry's mod in the way that you make it what you want it to be, be it an adventure RPG, Modern day RP or perhaps a zombie survival Left 4 Dead.

At least around 400-800 people are playing blockland at any given time, so it's far from dead, my only complaint is that Badspot (The dev) removed premade maps from the game, meaning any terrian you want to have you have to build yourself or download it from someone else.

The game runs smoothly on most PCs so don't worry about your system specs and is a game i recommend to anyone who enjoys Garry's mod and or Legos, this game is a dream come true for me, hell, i even used to host the most popular medieval-rp server back in 2012.

Also, you're not limited to being a block person, you're able to play as any NPC or rigged vehicle, meaning playable dragon characters which you can customize with different colors, tanks, horses.ect (Yes peole can ride you)

Now when i said it's like Garry's mod meets Legos, i ment just that, in Garry's mod you have to download addons made by the community, which you can do ingame easily without any hassle, it's as simple as searching for a mod and click download.
Currently there's a massive amount of addons available from dragons, flintlock weapons, lasers, lego weapons, LOADS OF VEHICLES OH GOD, and gamemodes, not to mention custom builds like giant fantasy castles and what-not.

So to anyone who is unsure about the game or is turned off my the fact that there are blocks.
This /is/ a Garry's mod game, with Legos, and quite frankly i LOVE legos.

(PS, playable dragons and Hydralisk(StarCraft) characters are a massive upgrade from Garry's mod in my eyes, and considering how easy it is to create your own mods it's definitely worth picking up for those who have talent with Blender)

reviewText:
Just a minecraft rip-off you say? Never! This game is more than meets the eye, and whilst is unmistakably similar to the chart top, award winning phenomenon that is mine craft, it is very much its own ticket. Blockland is like all the fun parts of minecraft put at your feet, with all the incentive to accompany it and more. It’s more of a thrill ride than minecraft that encourages griefing and killing other players, needless to say this will give you endless amounts of laughs and surpise you for many hours.

If you managed to pick this up in a bundle, great! If not and you’re like for a pixelated fix, it’s worth every dollar!

reviewText:
WARNING!!! THIS GAME HAS ONE OF THE WORST COMMUNITIES EVER!

This has got to be one of the best sandbox games I have ever played. I bought it back in 2009 and have been playing it ever since. When I moved my game from the standard launcher to Steam, my friends asked about it. I recommended this game to them, and now, to you unsure buyers. Let's start with what you can do.

1. Build massive structures with a block limit of 256000 blocks
2. Drive around in a set amount of vehicles with rather good handling
3. Kill zombies, animals, and bots
4. Paint blocks to create art
5. Add effects and lights to bricks to make an already impressive structure look better
6. Mods! Make your game WAY better with more bricks, weapons, vehicles, paint, decals, etc!
7. Build signs out of individual bricks
8. Be a better person than anybody in the community
9. Build and fight with your friends and other players
10. Customize your character with different faces, body decals, and even a few hats.

AND MUCH MORE!

TL;DR
This game is incredible, but has a terrible community.

reviewText:
My hours on Steam are too small, I've been playing Blockland since 2010.

The community in-game of less than 500 at any given time is 70% little kids. The game hasn't been updated since December 23rd, 2015 if you're counting bug fixes. Don't count bug fixes, and the last major update was February 5th, 2012. The server list will have a wave of empty servers and 5 that are on and nearly full every day. Those 5 are the same gamemodes 24/7. Don't expect to host a server people will like, only popular people have more than 5 people on at once. Even then, 2 of the 5 will be afk.

The forum is much more active, given not only people discussing the game but anything they feel like in the Off-Topic sections. 70% of these people do not play Blockland anymore. The community is toxic to even the slightest mistakes, as random arguments and outbursts are expected from a website full of teenagers and smug college students.
Trolls get away with baiting daily and nobody can say anything without spawning a 50 page argument that devolves into a discussion on which anime to watch. You aren't allowed to tell someone you don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about their topic no matter how much you want to because its against the rules. Much like in-game, your forum threads will die unless they are interesting or you are popular. If you join, you will be accused of being an alt (or alternate account) no matter what, no exceptions. The developer reserves the right to ban you at any point for the slightest slip-up while add-on creators practically take over game development for him.

But it has legos, which is nice.

reviewText:
AUDIO: Basic                                                             AESTHETIC: Lego
MEMORABILITY: Good                                           WORTH: Heavy Discount

PROS: Lots of building options, tons of color, texture and block shape options to build just about anything you put your mind to. Mount, weapon, and interactive options galore.

CONS: Community appears to be entirely made up of very young children. There also appears to be no options for spawned features/copy-paste in worlds, meaning that you will have to download or make maps entirely by yourself, piece-by-piece. Controls are very complex.

OVERALL: A lot of people say this game peaked about 5 years ago or so. I wouldn't know, because I wasn't there-- But it is clear that this game is full of potential that is not being utilized for one reason or another. It's disappointing that I will not be able to do much with my creations beyond screenshot them or show them to close friends who also own this.

SCORE: 5/10

reviewText:
A HORRENDOUS FAILURE OF A GAME!!

Okay, where do I begin?
I guess I should say it's not the game that's cancer, its the community. Look on the game's official forum for proof. There is literally an ENITRE THREAD DEDICATED TOWARDS FLAMING OTHER USERS!!!
Not only that, but you have many, many people (Kids and adults) that do NOT act thier age whatsoever. And with a large portion of the community having mental illnesses such as Autism, it can be very annoying at most times. (Im not saying people with a legitimate mental illness are bad, but they can be annoying without even knowing it)

Now, there is some good with this game. The user-created content back from around 2010 still remains extremely popular today, and builds, bricks, weapons, and tools still remain extremely fun to mess around with today, in the game's single player. There are even brick add-ons that add even more actual LEGO blocks to the game!

However, in conclusion, your $10 dollars would be MUCH better spent on a different game, perhaps one of the older GTA games? Or maybe a few case keys in CSGO?

Or, best of all, you could take the $10 you were going to use on virtual Legos and go out to any old toy store and buy yourself some REAL Legos!

It'd pry be more fun than this game anyways...

This game is definately worth your time and money.

reviewText:
I'm not sure I'll be able to put my feelings for this game in words as eloquently as some of the other reviews here, but I'll do my best.

I would like to start off by saying that I have, at the very least, 2000 hours logged into this game pre-steam. Blockland is the first game I ever bought, almost 6 years ago. Holy ♥♥♥♥. Back then, it was still $20, and I can tell you now that I would have paid five times that amount back then if I knew how much I would have loved it.

Other people have already explained the building system and the events system, so I won't really talk about those. What I would like to talk about, however, is the add-on creation system. Don't get me wrong, I truly enjoy building and eventing, but I wouldn't keep coming back to this game as often as I do if there weren't any add-ons. Not even just using add-ons though. More than that: creating them, changing them, collaborating on them. Even though some of the coding may be limited by the engine in this game, it more than makes up for this by flattening the learning curve for making your own mods. In my honest opinion, there are way more possibilities for creativity because of this. Because more people are making add-ons, there is a lot more diversity and plenty of originality when it comes to gamemodes, server mods, etc.

The reason why I said at the very least
recommended: is because of all the time I've spent in text editors
hoursPlayed: writing code. That's actually the reason why you won't see many hours played on my steam account for Blockland
voteText: I'm in the midst of making a big gamemode (look for it
helpfulPercent: people of the future). This game is where I learned how to do basic logic constructions and other similar things for writing code. The language is called "torquescript"
votesHelpful: and it's pretty similar to C in most ways. It's incredibly easy to learn because of the syntax checker (to catch any mistakes you make)

reviewText:
This game is mind-blowingly awesome. You want to abuse rapid firing rockets via an event system or just want to build a humble little home? Well, here's your solution.

I reccomend the first thing you'd want to do is go to Start A Game and click on the Tutorial gamemode. Then start this game and make it singleplayer and follow the steps shown on screen.

The game uses an easy to install add-on system, which is basically finding the Steam directory on your computer (Windows: Steam > SteamApps > Common > Blockland) and dragging and dropping your selected file into the AddOns Folder. I think this system will eventually be modded and changed to work with Steam Workshop like Garry's Mod. Once you have the right addons and knowledge of how to use them, the possibilities for a good server are endless.

The building mechanics are very simple once you get the hang of them - simply using the numpad/your selected control scheme to maneuver the blocks into the right place and pressing Enter  when your ''Ghost Brick (Invisible brick you will see when you click the ground to move a block around) is above a support or another block. Then you can use the Paint Can (default key is E) to paint this block a selected colour.

Physics-wise, this game is absolutely mad. If you think it's hilarious to have your car flung into oblivion then this game is definitely the one you want. This also kind of falls into the category of graphics. This game's visuals are not the best, but definitely better than Minecraft's. (Sorry Notch.)

The game uses an eventing system which is a basic scripting mechanism. I think there should be a guide somewhere on the magic that is the Steam page, and that also tells you the rest about the game.


Also, little LEGO guys.
They're so cute.


10/10 would build giant castle again.

reviewText: This is my favorite PC game of all time. If you like to build things, this is one of the best games you can get to do so. There are tons of things you can do in this game, like creating DMs, RPGs, racing builds, and sports arenas. You name it and you can probably build it. You can easily make the things you want to build with good building controls and a nice, clean user interface. Plus there is even a very useful event system that you can use, so you can turn a light switch on or off, create bots to interact with your build, and much, much more. reviewText: Okay, I've been playing the game since around 2007, while having varying interest in the game up until the present day. From version 9 and up, it was a great game, nearly everyone ♥♥♥♥ their pants when they heard about a new update because it brought new content to the table. Now it's rarely updated with versions that would constitute themselves more as a hotfix rather than anything else. We've arrived at the end of blockland's development and Badspot has practically lost all interest in the game. Is this a bad thing? For me, not really, seeing as there are always modders and mapmakers ready to enhance the game's experience. Let me tell you, there are many mods out there to suit your tastes, so I hope you'll never be bored with the different possibilities. As far as creativity goes, you can go all out and push the limits of the game if you have to. It's basic lego building but with the ability to not go out to your local toys r us and dropping 30+ on a set of legos. You can also play mini-games and other stuff in these worlds that you build.\n\nSo to make things brief, the game is great. Go ahead and pick it up, it's only ~$10, try it out. If you don't like it, you didn't waste much.

reviewText:
I've been playing this game since 2009, and I am so glad it made it to steam.

In short, this game is Garry's Mod, but made out of bricks. Let your creativity run wild to construct cities, spaceships, and so much more. Have fun in in various minigames ranging from TDMs to City RPs. Events let you change the behavior of bricks, from changing colours when clicked to managing an item shop. This game's only limitation is truly its players' imagination. What is missing from the stock game can be found on the forums in the form of Add-Ons, which expand the game's content, by adding bricks, vehicles, weapons, gamemodes and a myriad of other miscellaneous improvements or changes.

I'd recommend it to players who appreciate the sandbox genre and any lego fan.

reviewText:
I dreamed about a game like this since I was a kid. Played this game since it was first freeware (2004); the upgrade to retail in 2007 was worth it. I'd have more hours on this than TF2, if I'd kept track before the Steam edition.

This game taught me about art, scene design, project management, concepts of coding (events system and modifying game files), and teamwork; but the best part of it, was that I was just having a good old time building for TDM builds and helping out on RP servers.

When large projects start to feel like work, I can always start a minigame in the city I'm building to ski away from dinosaurs, or hop on a public minigame server to vent some steam. The instant chaotic action of TDMs, boss-fights, and, more recently for me, Speed Kart racing, does the trick quite well (I used to hate the idea of racing; that is, until silly physics-gone-mad collisions were involved). When I'm feeling more dedicated, I'll team up on a CTF, dogfight, or trench war server to satiate my tryhard tastes.
But when I get back to that big project, and it's finished, it's the greatest when others can appreciate and experience your creation by walking the halls. Or running down them. Away from bears with pistols akimbo.

A note for new builders: don't be intimidated by screenshots of massive-crazy-project builds. Start with what you know or feel is right. Your ability to create what you imagine will improve over time, like any art form, and will be greater scaling with the amount of time you put into it, and how many friends you have for work division and support.
I started this game quite young, and having people tell me something looked good or bad influenced me a lot (very common in that stage of development); but I learned to pay the most attention to those who gave reasoning. Find someone like that, or be that person for someone-- they matter the most.

reviewText:
Blockland mainly use's the numberpad adjacent to your arrow key's ' on most keyboard's ' for building. Yes most of the control's in Blockland are bindable, but why this is set to default for Blockland's building system is another. This game's building system allow's for remarkable ammount's of detail, despite being locked to a grid system, being able to rotate brick's, move them up and down and right to left so this design choice is mostly justified.

This game work's on a grid based system of 1x1.

This game is not restricted to just rectangle's and cube's as there are also round's, ramp's and special brick type catagorie's for you to experiment with.

Blockland's default weaponry and tool's is quite small, but thank's to blockland's incredible modability, this can be easily solved.

If you are looking for a sandbox game, I would most likely reccomend this for you.

reviewText:
This game is great, it's by far my favorite that I've ever played. I've had it for roughly 2 years, and have been at my computer, playing this game, for over 35 days. That's over 840 hours.

Pros:
Good graphics (if your computer can handle them)
Tons and tons of add-ons
Really good building system once you learn it
You can do just about anything with enough time
Legos+Garry's Mod=Blockland

Cons:
It can take a while to get used to building with it
Small community. This is why YOU should buy this game. We need more players!

A lot of people talk about how bad the community is. In some ways it is bad. BUT, there are still a lot of nice people who are willing to help the new players learn the ropes. I personally enjoy it when I get to teach new players how to do things, it's just an awesome experience where I get to help people, which is something I love. Yes, the community is  mixed bunch, there are little kids, there are idiots, there a simply mean people. But, there's also nice people.

reviewText: I have been on Blockland for around 4.5 years, and is still not even near old. Every time I turn it on, there's always something to do, if you have a creative mind, this game is perfect for you. You can make nearly anything, houses, citys, spaceships, e.t.c. Even though the game comes with some default items, bricks e.t.c, there is a giant bunch of add-ons you can add to the game, to make it even more fun. Even though the loss of interiors and terrain has happened, the game is still as fun as ever. Blockland also has an event system, where you can make stuff happen, like make bricks dissapear, have them change color, and with Event add-ons, that's even fun too. The price used to be £18, and I think the game is worth it, and now, it's £7, so now you can have the same fun, for a good price, I am not even the tinyest bit annoyed about how I had to pay £17 and not £7, as Badspot (the creator) fully deserves it. I'm sorry for the giant review, but that's just how great and fun this game is. I could never understand how people can not like this game, as it's packed with a ton of stuff to do. I'd recommend this to everyone.

reviewText: When I first discovered this game, I saw it as as simplified version of Minecraft with Legos. However, upon watching videos, reading articles, browsing the forum, and ultimately purchasing and playing the game, I discovered there was much more than meets the eye. The simple, yet intuitive tutorial introduces you to the basics of the game without overloading you with information and walls of text. It gives you the freedom to learn many of the amazing things available in the world of Blockland by yourself, furthering the satisfaction value of this game. There are so many things to discover in the 50 or so megabytes of initial download, and endless possibilities to further expand gameplay with scores of user-created addons and mods. This is without a doubt, the most versatile game you will find on the market.

reviewText:
Blockland describes itself as 'that game where you build stuff'. That's actually pretty accurate!

Content
Blockland runs on an older version of the Torque Game Engine. It revolves around what are essentially legos, as the title implies. You control a small plastic figure called a 'blockhead', and the core element of the game involves placing bricks (with very intuitive controls) and then changing them with paint, emitters, or a simple programming system to create pretty much anything. There's support for add-ons and a weapon system, which opens possibilities for team deathmatches and any number of other gamemodes.

Positive
The controls. Blockland's movement and view controls are similar to any other 3D game - WASD to move, mouse to look, space to jump, so on, so forth. The build controls are almost as easy to use. Pressing a numpad key moves the brick in that direction, just like WASD; the corner keys move up and down or rotate the brick, and numpad 0 clears your 'ghost' brick (which shows where you're going to place it). This does take a day or two to learn well, but once you figure it out it's hard to think of a better way.
Blockland also has decent multiplayer features, and involves a player-hosted server system. One of the core elements of the game is the fact that you're not just building stuff - you're all building stuff together. Servers can, by default, support up to 32 players; a workaround has been used to increase this to 99. The fact that servers are player-hosted removes most problems with lag; each individual server has to have a poor connection to be affected, instead of just one master server (there is, in fact, a master server, but it only keeps a list of all the servers players are hosting; IP connections can still be used).
Bricks can be 'evented', or programmed, to do a number of things. The events system acts on a per-brick basis and is actually very easy to understand. You choose an input from a drop-down box - like onActivate (when the brick is clicked) or onPlayerTouch (more self-explanatory), then a target (Player, Client, Brick, Named Brick, etc.), then an action (setColor, Kill, playSound). For example - onActivate -> Player -> addVelocity(0, 0, 10) would make a ladder rung, when clicked, give the player a boost up. More than one event can be placed on a brick, and they can be delayed or even chained together with something called a relay.
Finally, Blockland has an extensive add-on system that can be used to change almost any part of the game. New bricks can be added, or emitters, or colors, or events, or any other number of things. Even the GUI is open for change; the only rules are those that the programming language sets. The programming language is, however, slightly limited by the game's creator; this is mostly to avoid hacking or cheating, which are nigh-impossible without illegally modifying the game.

Negative
First - the game carries the potential for what I call minecraft syndrome. You buy the game and just LOVE it; then you play it for several weeks or months and abruptly lose all interest. I first encountered this effect while playing Minecraft, hence the name; I used to play both games constantly, and now I haven't touched either of them for months for no apparent reason.
Secondly, the game's community can be picky. Just mentioning Minecraft as above might get me some insults and complaints; half of Blockland's community is notorious for their hate of the games Minecraft and Roblox, the sole reason appearing to be that they're similar to Blockland (or vice verse). Also, the game has a website with a forum; there's a good share of good people as well as an impressive number of idiots that can be found there. The community isn't horrible, but it isn't the greatest I've seen, either.
Finally, the game lost some of its former value with the v21 update. This update removed terrains and interiors - excellent parts of the game that allowed landscapes and buildings to be used as the scene for construction - in favor of shaders (like you might find in any other game) and bots (what it says on the tin). The game wasn't ruined, but it was definitely made worse. Terrains and interiors may return, and I hope they do, but having to build on an infinite flat plane shouldn't hinder your creativity!

Summary
Blockland's features outweigh its flaws - while the community could be nicer and some recent updates are questionable, the game has a solid base and a good number of features to support it. Its support for add-ons and mods make almost anything possible, and there's already a great number of these out there. If you enjoyed building with legos as a kid, consider yourself a decent artist, need practice with programming, or just want a good way to have fun with your friends - this game is for you.

reviewText: This game ate up my afternoons before the Steam release. This game is probably one of the best sandbox building block games I've played, probably even the best sandbox game I've played period. The base game has a ton of content, but mods add even more and I'm sure there's a mod for everyone. Multiplayer is fantastic with a huge variety of player-made gamemodes as well as a fun-loving, yet mature community. The visuals look gorgeous (Especially with shaders on.), the physics are a treat to see (Especially if you blow up a building made up entirely of small blocks.) and each server level has a completely different atmosphere. I absolutely love this game and I recommend you get it if you love sandbox games and the Lego-filled memories of your childhood.

reviewText:
I grew up playing the original alpha of this game, it was called Blockland v00002, lagged like a mofo and it was barely playable on my Pentium 4 PC. But, most importantly, it was fun.

Then a bunch of years later, this game came out - and it is just absolutely amazing. Think of it as a sort of lego-builder's Garry's Mod. Sure, you've got your great building tools to make awesome ♥♥♥♥ with your friends in the default sandbox mode, within the limitations (it's still lego, so you can't have any floating bricks, for example), but apart from that, anyone can create new weapons, vehicles, and entirely new gamemodes with the game's scripting language (the uh, not terribly excellent TorqueScript).

And the builds you make can be enhanced with event bricks, which are basically interactive bricks that'll react to say, a player walking on it, in ways that you define in the game with a simple system. Some dude made a playable pong using that, which is batshit crazy. And awesome.

All in all, I can't find a good way to end this, because I'm not a writer, but I really, truly love this game, and I wish more people would play it with me.

Game of the year, every year, 10/10.

reviewText:
PROS:
- Gameplay is fun and simple
- Numbpad brick placement is fantastic and easy to use
- Multiplayer custom gamemodes and add-ons are endless
- Character customization is easy and can make for some pretty hilarious character costumes

CONS:
- Graphics are not optimized for ♥♥♥♥
- Multiplayer Community is mostly dominated by cocky players (Hence, I said mostly)
- Single-player can be boring. Otherwise there is no actual feedback from the game to the player.

OVERVIEW:
I have played games like Roblox, Minecraft and Ace of Spades, and find joy in those games because of the community's creative standpoint, and Blockland is no exception. This game is the easiest one to pick up because it ACTUALLY HAS A TUTORIAL! (Which is still dumb because you have to load it up, there is no Tutorial" button anywhere so you're left to find it yourself.) The controls are easy AND difficult. If you're used to FPS controls of switching through your weapons using 1

reviewText:
Revised 11/25/2015:
Good game, ♥♥♥♥ tier community and servers.

The building and movement controls are oddly satisfying for a game of its genre, featuring a myriad of bricks to build with, and a robust add-on system allows for infinitely more game content than what the vanilla game offers.

However, the community's been taken over by little children and decent servers are difficult to come by. Your best bet is to get some of your friends to buy this game (if they don't already have it this is) and hang out with them on a private server where you can ♥♥♥♥ around without interference from unwanted visitors.
