reviewText: Blockland has been around for a long time, and has sadly been burried. People still play, but it lost so much popularity. It's a fun sandbox building game where you can build and program anything. The way you build stuff is very similar to real-life LEGOs, where you are not allowed to have floating bricks. The law of gravity is impossible to break. You can still make bricks float by making invisible and walk through towers under a brick. You can press the left mouse button to activate your jets so you can fly around. There's a spray can that allows you to not only paint bricks, but give them special effects such as rainbows and also make bricks transparent. You start with three tools; a hammer, a wrench, and a printing gun. The hammer lets you break bricks you put, but you can't break bricks under another brick unless the brick you want to destroy won't cause the other bricks above to float in the air. You can type /wand to get a wand that acts just like a hammer, but if you destroy a brick that would cause any bricks above it to float, everything above it breaks also. The wrench lets you do many different things with your bricks. While holding the wrench, you can click on a brick to view its properties. You can make your brick emit fire, or smoke, or any other particle that's in the game. You can spawn more tools, like a sword or a gun, or something that'll help you build better things. You can also program your bricks with events. Events are super easy to learn. I made a basic Windows XP computer with very little knowledge of events when I was a noob, and the results were satisfactory! The properties will be different depending on the brick you select. For example, if I use the wrench on a vehicle spawner, I won't have the ability to make it into a spear giver. I can only select from a list of rideable objects. If I use the wrench on a music brick, I will be able to choose from a list of music for it to play. The printer gun lets you put pictures on printer bricks. It's useful for making signs for things like stores, or for cooler security systems. Building in Blockland is lots of fun! You can also download add-ons that other users made from other websites so you can get more content such as more guns and swords to blow up everyone, or tools to help you build better things. I hope Steam workshop comes out for this game soon so it'll be quicker to download and find add-ons. Blockland also has a minigame feature which lets you disable and enable certain fuctions such as building or jets and allow players to get points for doing certain tasks. With add-ons, you can enhance your minigames and make them even more fun to play with your friends. You could make a futuristic team deathmatch minigame, or a survival horror game using the popular Renderman add-on based on the legendary Renderman! This game has endless possibilities, and I am really sad to see it die like this. I mean it. I am literally sad. After the extremely popular Return to Blockland add-on was gone, many people started to give up on this game. Return to Blockland made Blockland more social by adding private chat (much like Steam's chat), friends, and the ability to join your friend in a server they are playing. It didn't just make Blockland a better game to play it friends. It gave you better admin tools. It allowed you to download add-ons very similar to how Steam workshop works. Many add-ons lost some functions because they depended on RTB. The Renderman add-on was one of them. You can't control when he spawns anymore. I will always remember how much fun Blockland was. R.I.P. one of my favorite sandbox games ever.

Already worth the money someone else spent on this game.

reviewText:
Best game I have ever played. People may say the community is bad, which may be true, but if you're still a little kid you could just turn the cuss filter on. I personally would rather have this community compaired to Minecraft or Roblox, or maybe even Gmod. It's just the way a lot of games are.

Anyways, here's why I recommend Blockland;

•Lots and lots of add-ons! You could get anything from cars to doors, to gamemodes (including Super Murder Mystery, which is my all time favorite. This gamemode includes a few players who are in the mafia, who have to kill everyone else.)

•Small community, meaning a better chance of running in to the same person multiple times, helping you make friends.

TL;DR, Awesome game, little kids just keep your swear filter on. Best game I've ever played.

Over all, I'd rate this game 9.5/10.

reviewText:
The Hard Truth
Listen up ladies and gents, here is the story. Blockland was a wonderful prosperous game. Great community and servers. The game was in its prime with maps and players everyone helping others build massive cities and gamemodes for all around to enjoy. Then v21 came out and took out these wonderful maps. Lots of players stopped joining these great servers and leaving the game altogether. There was still a lot of players left to build up from the rubble of this update. After a while the community slowly died. Then it hit, RTB shut down. This was the soul of the game, it held all the players' ideas and creations. Thus with this community website shutting down, it killed this game. Servers are barren, players are dazed and confused, creations dwindled. The game hit its peak then dropped harder than it should have. It's still a wonderful game it's just there are about a max population of 300 players on a day with about 90 or so servers up. About 30% of servers will have 0-2 players just sitting there, doing nothing.

Story brought to you by loads of hours of offline steam play before it hit the greenlight. Still recommending this because it's still fun with a group of friends.

reviewText:
I have played this game on and off since 2007. One of the coolest things back in the day was being part of a building clan. For the most part, those days are over with the exception of a few withstanding groups. However, the community (at least most of it) is still very good, and I'm sure new subcommunities will form with an influx of new people.

The possibilities in this game are literally endless, especially with the advantage of the RTB Mod, which allows you to access a database of add-ons for your game as well as communicate with others who are currently in the game.

It takes a bit of patience to master the controls, but success comes through persistence (though persistantly asking for admin in a server will get you kicked!!!).

I can't wait to see what's in store for Blockland as far as new game-modes, mods, and people! Don't be a Blockhead... buy this game!

reviewText: The story of an ex-convict recently released from prison, out to get revenge on his oppresive captors. He does this in various ways; Petty vandilisim, assault, Pirate Ship Deathmatchs, etc. The game requires an intellectual approach to its many secrets and story branches.You must be patient with this game, as dying is something that will happen regularly and unexpectedly. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys story-rich games, with a deep narrative and a rich backdrop that immerses you completely. Upon starting the game, you will be greeted with some of the best graphics currently available to the gaming industry. However this is only a small part of the fun and excitement Blockland delivers.\n10/10 Would buy again.

reviewText: This game is one of the best lego building games I have ever played. The game implements such great and innovative ideas that I can never go back to roblox or minecraft. There are no griefers online because of the games trust" system. People can't build on your bricks unless you grant them trust (which you can give them through the player list GUI). There are two types of trust: the first type is build trust were people are allowed to build on your bricks
date: the second type is full trust were people are allowed to modify and delete your bricks. You can also demote someone's trust or take it away from them entirely so they can't build on your stuff.\n\nThe administrative options are great as well. If someone spammed bricks all over your server you don't have to manually clean them up. Instead the admin GUI allows you to clear all the bricks of a specific user. You can also choose to spy on a person through the GUI to see if they are misbehaving. You can also load a save that you built before if you are an admin so you dont have to always build everything up on a server. There are also two different types of admins: admin and super admin. An ordinary admin can ban
recommended: admin orb (fly around and go through bricks) and load bricks. A super admin can do all that but it can also deadmin ordinary admins and ban them
hoursPlayed: they can also change what mods and gamemode is on the server as well.\n\nAnother great thing is the event system. This allows you to create simple function with your bricks. So if you want to can have so when you click on a certain brick it disappears
voteText: or have a building explode when you step over a brick. The game also has bots that you can also event. This allows you to change their appearance
helpfulPercent: their weapon
votesHelpful: if they are an ally or enemy
votesTotal: and much more. You can also apply lights to bricks and emitters which add smoke
votesFunny: grass
commentsCount: and different effects. This adds much more life to your builds and instead of just making a build for people to look at on a free build. You can create an adventure were people have to battle bots or have to collect keys to open doors.\n\nThe minigame system is also amazing. With this system people can create their own game within the game. This allows them to select a playertype
column16: select what weapons to start out with
column17: etc. then invite people to join it. So people can be DMing on a free build of they want but this won't affect the people who didn't join the minigame. So you can have people fighting in a deathmatch
column18: people racing
column19: and people happily building all on the same server (the minigame system can be disabled if you want).\n\nThe game also very moddible which keeps the game fresh. Installing a mod is very easy. Just put the zip into the adding folder
column20: enable it in the custom game mode option and your done. There is also a mod called "return to blockland" which allows you to download mods ingame. The mods can be adding more vehicles
column21: more events
column22: different skyboxes
column23: different bricks
column24:
basically anything. There is also a type of mod called a gamemode which packages a bunch of different addons into one and loads save and different gamemode options.

The only real flaw of the game is that there aren't a big variety of servers up due to the community being so small. But the great thing is that you can create just about anything and it allows you to set up your own server without port forwarding so you can just create any type of server you want.

I would recommend this game to anyone who likes building and Legos. Even to people who don't because there is such a large variety of things to do. This is the best building game I have played and puts other building games to shame."

reviewText:
Preface: I've had this game since 2010 back in v16 and it has changed a LOT since then.  I've watched the community grow and change and I've probably spent several hundred hours on the game before it came to Steam.

Blockland is a creative sandbox game created in 2004 by Badspot.  A lot of people say it's kind of like Lego Garry's Mod, which isn't far from the truth.  I love this game to pieces and always have, but it does have certain flaws that can seriously hinder the experience at times.

The game is great because you can do nearly anything, but the community is a bit... strange, at times.  There are two groups of people in the game: the noobs that don't know how anything works, and the old-timers that are either very supportive of newcomers or are spiteful towards them.  There's not much middle ground between these groups and quite a lot of the veteran players have left the game since v21 was released, a few months before the game came to Steam.

The biggest actual gameplay drawbacks will be very obvious within the first couple hours of playing: a bad physics engine and subpar graphics.  The physics engine has been buggy and unpredictable since the game's creation, although the graphics are actually substantially better now than before.

Possibly the only thing that has really kept me playing the game this long is the giant amount of user-made content that can be found on the official forums.  The custom add-ons really bring the game to life and it's somewhat bland without them.  Nearly every popular server runs many add-ons, allowing for an even more custom and unique experience.

Due to its Garry's Mod-like sandbox nature, Blockland has also inspired several notable video makers on YouTube, including Teneksi, Filipe1020, 8bitcube, Flubbman97, SirHerg1, and others.

I'm trying not to be too wordy, so I'll just do pros and cons now cuz I'm boring like that.

Pros:

- Great building system allowing for near-endless creativity
- Lots of great public servers to join
- Huge catalog of mods and add-ons
- Not difficult to set up a server (can be tricky sometimes if your internet is weird)
- Community has lots of nice people that will help new players learn the game
- Low price

Cons:

- Buggy physics
- Average graphics
- Controls can take a while to get used to
- Not frequently updated (back in the day there was usually an update every couple weeks or so, but there hasn't been anything major since January 2014 as of this review)
- Community has lots of trolls

The community is both a pro and a con because depending on who you meet, it could really go either way.

Overall, I would say the game is definitely one of my favorite games of all time and even if you don't like it, it's only $10 USD spent.  That's really all there is to say about the game, and I hope you try it out!
voteText: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I don't have any previous history of the game before it came to Steam, and really don't care about some of the politics that surround the title.  My opinions are based on my play experiences.

I don't think it's fair to compare this to LEGO in anyway.  The blocks in the game do not go together in the ways that real LEGO bricks do.  For example I never found a way to change the direction of studs (SNOT building).  And the selection of blocks is very minimal without installing a bunch of extra mods or add-ons.

In fact, the game seems to require a certain amount of user-created material to be something other than demo or alpha quality.  So if you're just looking for a fun out-of-the-box experience, look elsewhere.

reviewText: i've basically grown up with this game. it's one of the best games i've ever played as far as overall experience goes. the community is one of the best i've ever seen. the modding capabilities are better than any game that i know of, and the modding community is helpful and generous. it says a lot when it's common practice for people to volunteer their help on mod projects with nothing in return. the people i've met on this game make up the majority of my friends list and you're all wonderful. from a gameplay point of view, it's one of the best sandboxes out there. the building works well and the eventing system opens up a world of capabilities, even on a vanilla install (if you know what you're doing). and with the mods available, a whole world of possibilities open up. i would recommend this game to anyone and everyone without any hesitation. if you don't have it, get it as soon as possible. five thumbs up, two out of two stars.

reviewText: I have thoroughly played this and helped it's development for around 10 years now. This is not a game where you learn how to play it in a month. This game takes a while to master the controls and knowledge of it. It is probably the most flexible, while still remaining stable, sandbox game I have ever played in my lifetime. Yes, it may seem like Roblox's evil cousin or a Minecraft rip-off or whatever, but it has one thing each of those doesn't; A fun-loving and creative community. Each modder is a valuable member of the community, infact; a lot of dedicated people (regular everyday gaming people) have been recruited into the staff more often than you may think.\n\nPeople will play this for a few weeks, not like it, and turn it down. Which is fine, this game may not be for everyone, but the reason this takes a while to get used to is because there's really no other game like it. It's like stepping into high school for the first time. It's different. Yes, every game has it's share of bad sports, trolls, and idiots, but once you look into the community and spend some time to master the controls, you can literally do anything you want. This game is a First Person Shooter, Role-Playing Game, Arcade Game, and so much more. And for those of you who have already given up on the game, I ask you to give it one more shot, to spend time to know how to work the game, and really let your imagination go wild. Everything you see in the photo previews were all built by humans who started out in your shoes. There is really no limits. Every statement where people say If you can imagine it

reviewText:
I've owned this game for six years and I can say that when I reach absolute boredom with all of the garbage-tier AAA titles that come out this is my first fallback.  There's always something to do whether it be building an elaborate city by myself, entering a trench TDM and completely dominating, or sitting enjoying my time with others. This game had so much potential when I first played it, and now I'm seeing these potentials become real game elements. The mod development group cranks out new stuff almost by the minute.  I've even released stuff myself. It's also really optimized and could literally be played on your grandmother's computer.

I'm really impressed with everything Badspot has done with Blockland. I would guess he is probably swamped with things to do since this game has blown up on Steam, but he still takes the time to engage the community.  My hat is off to you, bro.

Anyways, if you are looking for The Game"

reviewText:
The game is great when you have enough people playing local, but most of the regular multiplayer is too laggy to be fair. But don't get me wrong, this game is still tons of fun! Similar to Garry's mod, it is easlily added on to, there are goals only set by the players, and there are TONS of halarious moments.

First, I want to start with the gameplay.
It is about as rock solid as the game will ever get. Blockland appeals to a broad audience through it's open ended ways of playing. For instance, you can build if you are into creativity. Lets say that you don't care for building, that is not a problem. You could join a multiplayer kart race, deathmatch or some other original gamemode that Blockland could boast. The only thing bogging this part down is the slow multiplayer connections and the TERRIBLE physics. And by TERRIBLE, I mean if you hit somebody with a car just right, or should I say wrong, you could in fact get a one way ticket to the statosphere. (Then again, it's not exactly bad when it happens to your friend, in fact that's halarious). If you have a good internet connection, then this game's multiplayer will appeal to you.

Well, I don't really have another category to cover so...


Pros-

* Been around for 7 years, still active updates (sorta).
* Easy to mod
* Fun Multiplayer
* Creative Structure
* Solid, refined gameplay concepts
* I have had no problems with the community so far
* Good graphics for a block game.
* Makes halarious moments with or without friends around

Cons-

* The physics can be beyond bad.
* Bad multiplayer connections.
* Did I mention the physics?
* Setting up a multiplayer server is brutally hard. (not really their fault)
(EDIT: I found a few more)
*The public multiplayer has the worst community you will ever witness.
*Lack of ambition (The game feels like it's becoming more and more abandoned each day)


In my opinion, this game is solid enough to achieve a 8.9/10

Im sure people will like it, but DEFINETLY NOT everyone.
But for only ten dollars, it's one of the greatest user created content games that predates minecraft.

reviewText:
If you like minecraft but wish for a bit more freedom for your creativity, this might be it.
Its almost litterally LEGO on your pc, but with some basic options that allow amazing things.

Fighter jets, replica of PONG, musical stairs, pirate battles you name it.
And just click a block with the wrench tool and have it do something amazing when touched/looked at/used etc.

Multiplayer serves are where the fun really gets going though, and there are some amazing custom gamemodes that work right out of the box, no mods needed.

You wont shake the feeling you are playing legos+ in a hurry though, so if thats not your cup of tea then this isnt for you.

reviewText: Ah this is such a great game. I've had this game for over 5 years and put in over 1000 hours into it before it came to steam, it's the best sandbox game I've ever played because there is just so much you can do. I may have been just a kid when I first bought this game, but it is still amazing, I would reccommend this game over Garry's Mod because of it's great build system, gamemodes, and events system, which allows you to manipulate items and do amazing things. For a simple example, if you use events on a block, you could make it so that by touching the block you go flying into the air with your butt on fire. There are numerous possibilities with this game, it's simeoultaneously a FPS shooter, a 3rd Person Shooter, a racing simulator, a Dogfight simulator, a Quake-Like Deathmatch arena, a City RPG, a Jail RPG, and anything you can possibily think of. This is all thanks to the numerous enjoyable addons created by the community such as different gamemodes and addons. Very very underrated for it's quality as a game. People try to compare this game Roblox and then subsequently judge it based on that terrible game, but this should not be the case, because first of all it was created long before Roblox, second it has a much better community, third it has a much better building system, and fourth it has much more possibilities in terms of addons, gamemodes, and maps.

reviewText: I tried a demo for the game years ago, and had a bunch of fun with so little. Now I have the full game, and the possibilities are pretty much limitless. There is so much to do and/or create with Blockland. If you had a passion for Legos as a child, you might enjoy this game... a lot. It has the building mechanics of Legos, with the gameplay and versatility of Garry's Mod. The only setback for this game's potential is the community. There are always good people, but the majority seem to be pretty immature, but it's kind of expected for the type of game. Overall, I think it's a great game to have. It's very fun to play with friends! Also, feel free to check out my basketball server if you decide to buy.

reviewText:
Can't recommend it enough. I've played this on and off since 2008. Aside from building, there is always something new.

The modding community is huge. Hell, the game practically revolves around it. Vanilla is nice, but any server you join is going to have lots of mods. From Team Deathmatches, to racing, to prison escapes, to building with some friends, there are many things to keep you busy.

Development is always active, and with the new launcher introduced in Version 19, they're applied automatically and more frequently. There are always new content updates and bug fixes every once and a while. It's been like this for years, and doesn't seem to be slowing down.

The graphics are good for a sandbox building game, but what more could you want right? Shadows and shaders have been a nice addition in Version 21, and anyone with a non-intergrated graphics card can at least run them on minimum. The game isn't very demanding at all. Aside from the studs, the bricks looks and act like your classic Lego blocks, and the minifigures have a nice, original design to them.

In a nuthshell, this game is practically G-Mod in the style of Legos. And it can't get any better than that. If you're still unsure, there's a demo you can download to try out the game and mechanics yourself - aside from multiplayer. For an indie game that only costs twenty-dollars, you get a lot more than your money's worth.

reviewText:
(9.2) Blockland is not just one of those generic, lego-style sandbox type of game. Blockland is different in every aspect, foremost with the community. This game has no boundaries, especially with the use of mods. You cannot undermine this game for its lego-style approach, because beyond that you have unraveled limitless, unique possibilities that could be expressed through many game styles and modes. The well-sized and expanding community is helpful and the developer does a superb job at connecting with his players. As well, it features TorqueScript, an easy scripting language. It's super-cheap for its value!

My final premise on this title: This is an uncomparable, well-developed sandbox that is a definite must-buy for its pricing and community.

reviewText:
If you like minecraft but wish for a bit more freedom for your creativity, this might be it.
Its almost litterally LEGO on your pc, but with some basic options that allow amazing things.

Fighter jets, replica of PONG, musical stairs, pirate battles you name it.
And just click a block with the wrench tool and have it do something amazing when touched/looked at/used etc.

Multiplayer serves are where the fun really gets going though, and there are some amazing custom gamemodes that work right out of the box, no mods needed.

You wont shake the feeling you are playing legos+ in a hurry though, so if thats not your cup of tea then this isnt for you.

reviewText:
Game rating overall- 7/10

The good things about Blockland:
- The gameplay style
- Based off LEGO
- Add-ons(Workshop shoul be created)
- LEGOfied Garrys mod
- Online feature

The bad things about Blockland
- Issues that the creator is too lazy to fix
- The games community(Seriously, they ban players from the forums for ideas on improving the game.)
- Badmins
- Lazy Admins/Staff
- Newcomers(Possibly impaitient and annoying 8 year olds)

The game itself is great, but the community is a problem. The creator, Eric Hartman(A.K.A Badspot)May have made a wonderful game, but he's too lazy to fix any problems. He bans players off the forums for having such great ideas on improving the game. Overall, the online feature is WORSE. Theres tons of admin abusers, banning newcomers, banning anyone who they think is good enough to stay. Who cares if they are trustworthy? Anyhow, the servers like Tezuni's Prison escape, Boss battles Is possibly the bestest servers out there. With steam, you cant make dedicated servers, but you can play the game like if you had the paid from website edition, where you can make dedicated servers.

I give this game 7/10, Great and fantastic sandbox game, but creator needs to pay attention to his game's bugs and his game a little more. -Engicop

reviewText: My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through. I agreed. At 28
date: I have never touched a cigarette. I must say
recommended: I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it
hoursPlayed: because this game gave me cancer anyway."

reviewText:
I used to play Blockland back WAY before it was Greenlit. It's still fun to this day, but if you want to play Blockland, keep a few things in mind:

1. The community has gone on a bit of a decline. Blockland has many jerks in it, but it's still much better to play multiplayer. If you want to play Blockland, persuade some friends to get the game as well.

2. The base game alone is somewhat bland. You can still do many things, but it's MUCH better with add-ons! Just look up how to get add-ons, and you'll find plenty of guides!

reviewText:
Now, dont get me wrong. I LOVE this game, but with the influx of 5 year olds and the fact that Badspot (the game's developer) said that he wasn't updating the game further, it's gone down in quality.

reviewText: I'm bad at writing reviews. But I have to give blockland a few words.\n\nIt all started in 2011. I have no idea where I found it. I just did. I downloaded the demo, and screwed around. One day i was hanging out with a friend and i showed him this game, and I asked my mom if i could get the full version. Well she said yes and needless to say i freaked out. Played it every day 24/7. Over the years I've gotten better, and better, maps were removed, shaders were added, RTB came and went, i got better and building and PVP, ect. There are many great addons, and many ♥♥♥♥. The community isn't always the nicest but there's always that one guy who is really nice and plays on everyone's server. I don't play it with steam, but I have atleast 3 thousand hours. I also bought it when it was 20 dollars. Ten? Way more than worth it. 100/10 R8ing, buy it now. You have to.

reviewText: Blockland is awesome, It's a legendary building game where you build anything you want. The best of this game is shaders. The shaders are amazing. Textures, qualites, physics and more. Building can be hard at first, but. Once you get ust to it, you might build good builds in the future. Blockland is mainly about building. Building anything you want, from a house to a school! And there are many ways to build, some are fast but less efficent, some are slow but very efficent. Another important thing is combat. You can battle your friends or Bots in your map or in another server. Another thing is Socializing, most servers have E-Tard List filters, that prevent people from saying U or anything else. And chat spam protection, where if you talk too much, Blockland will block you only for a few matter of time. There is also a trust feature, where you can send Trust Invites to build on your friends or other people's builds. You can also make objects in your home, interact with them and more. Making them more detailed and beautiful. Blockland also haves mini-games, where you can use those to create short or long mini-games to battle your friends in your sandbox server.

reviewText:
This is a really good sandbox game! It's flexible (not as flexible as ROBLOX, though), and it's quite easy to set up certain game-modes. There's a large add-on archive which has lots of things that'll appeal to you.

You can create your own add-on with some scripting knowledge (lua, I believe), and a graphics software such as Blender. It can range from new zombie types to guns, to vehicles, to items like Night Vision goggles!

There's only one real issue that I may have noticed. The developer can be quite rude at times (sources are from the reviews + screenshots), and that the game really isn't updated often anymore. You don't really need updates to enjoy the game, though! Add-ons serve a large purpose.

reviewText: Blockland may look like a Minecraft or Roblox clone at first glance to some people,but it really isn't and it in itself is much more than that. So BL is a building game first made in 2004 in the V0002 state, the retail version was then released in 2007 with the latest version being V21. Have you've ever played with LEGO's as a kid or built something with them? Did you ever have fun with them? If yes, then Blockland is the game for you. The game allows you to build with a virtually unlimted amount of bricks (There's a 256,000 brick limt,but you can set your own limt on your own server). It also even features an in-game eventing system that allows you to do cool stuff with your bricks like make a door that open and closes or a light switch. The modding community is also pretty good with a good number of brick packs, vehicles, colorsets, music, and etc. The community itself isn't the best, but there really isn't a perfect community out there anyway. You may meet some bad players here and there,but if you stay away from the bad side of the community you'll be fine. The graphics are very blocky and legolike giving a very nice look especially for a old 2003 engine.There are shaders in the game,but they look very jaggy and bad and they're also very poorly optimized at it too.If you want to there are modifications that can help you make the shadows look smoother,but you'll need a great PC to get it done. I would really recomend this game to anybody if you like building games and don't worry you'll really get your money's worth, I've spent at least about 400hrs (With my old blid and steam blid combined) on the game and haven't stopped yet.\n\nNote: When you first get the game I would highly recommend getting RTB.

reviewText: The community is what you make it, development has been in a slump recently but this game is complete and has provided a lot of replayability and room for creativity for me and a lot of the friends I made on this game (note I have few hours on steam version but likely a few hundred before I got it on Steam). Many of the negative reviews are people complaining about the developer not consistently putting out free updates consistently even for years after release, despite a strong modding community, and these people also tend to be problem users that stir up drama with developers are other players on the forum. This game IS definitely worth it, and I dare someone to tell me why its not. There is some cruddy servers but there is also the occasionally great server, just like most sandbox multiplayer games. If you're remotely interested in a lego based sandbox building game, get this game.

reviewText:
I first discovered Blockland in 2009, and I fell in love with it. Combining my hours on and off of Steam I have accumulated some 2.4 thousand hours of gameplay.

The building system is complex as hell, and if you're not good with Legos then this really isn't for you. The game's fanbase has largely died out due to the death of RTB and maps (just go on the Blockland forums and look at old gallery topics or soemthing). Most of the servers that other people have started are cancer.

I think my point is that if you can have fun on your own, making your own games, building your own maps, hosting your own original servers, this is the game for you. If you've come because you want to ♥♥♥♥ around in prebaked maps and have laughs, search elsewhere.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've spent hours upon hours building everything from boats to castles to spaceships, and playing games with other people online, most likely making Blockland my second-most-played game of all time. This was a long, long time before the game appeared on Steam, however, so you'll just have to take my word for it. I have yet to find another sandbox building game that gives you the level of freedom that Blockland does, with an endless supply of user-created add-ons in the form of blocks, game-modes, and more. LEGO sets were one of my favorite toys as a child, so being able to not only have endless bricks to build with but also the ability to explore my creations up-close as a small minifigure and interact with them was a dream come true.

While some people will use their imagination to bring physical form to whatever they can think up, my forte was always recreating things from other media. Not the most creative thing in the world, but it was the most enjoyable for me. At various points I worked on reconstructing playable versions of Team Fortress 2's ctf_2fort, Pokemon's Kanto region, and the entirety of Portal, as well as a large-scale model of Halo's Rocket Launcher. My only regret is that I'm not very good at finishing what I've started, as the Rocket Launcher was the only thing that ever reached total completion.

Most people tend to complain about the userbase, but it's only as bad as any other place composed mostly of people in grade-school who haven't been a part of an online community before. Certain problematic users will insist this game is bad, but only because they've been punished for misbehaving time after time after time. Overall, it just takes time to adjust.

reviewText: I've owned this game for close to 6 years now. This was one of the very first games I ever bought for my pc, and to this day it remains one of my favorites. Removing interiors and terrain did sadden me, and I lost something that I was very familiar with, however I do not believe Blockland is headed in the wrong direction. Blockland still remains an infinite cesspool of ideas and fun, and although limited at first, the addition of addons as encouraged leaves for even more possibilities. Whether or not you are a skilled architect, intelligent coder, or a server host, someone somewhere has something fun waiting for you in Blockland, that game where you build stuff.

reviewText:
EDIT 2: ♥♥♥♥ my reviews just look at my hours


Original:
It may just look like a game where you just place bricks. Its alot more than that.

This game opens alot of opportunites. You go on, click the join game button and see a list of at least 20 servers. Theres always plently of servers open. Prision Escape, Fort Wars, FreeBuild, CTF, Diesease, Murder Mystrey, Bot Wars, Role-play severs, Speedkart and Deathrace are all good examples. Some are modded, some arent. Another good part of the game is the mods are automatically downloaded.

Edited in for popular demand: Minigames and eventing are amazing. Start up a mini game and make it the way you want. Turn the mini game to a capture the flag ot even a City RPG.
Eventing is even better. Event a brick so when you click on it, it plays a song or even tells you something. Make hidden rooms with disappering bricks, Make your bots look like you, Make traps so people fly into the air and so much more that i cant remember.

Sadly, on mac, It is a bit glitchy. You cant see any faces, when you start up the game it asks you to setup your settings and your player always resets.

Singleplayer is mostly good for nothing, unless you have some fun mods or you just want to mess around with bots or something.

It is still the funnest game ive ever played in history of games ive played. EDIT: e.g. ive played 200 hours of it. (and none of my other games have come close to that.)

Mods are hard to get, there are some websites that have archives of the epic website, RTB. (that is closed)

In all its such a fun game, but there are a few sad reasons of not to get it. I'd reccomend it to people that like: sandbox, building, fps, loling, role-playing, zombies and tf2 like games!!

reviewText:
Blockland is less of a game and more of a toolbox. It's definitely a sandbox more than it is anything else(don't believe what they tell you about 'adventure mode'!). It's a bit like Garry's Mod but a little more structured, if you've played that and would like a comparison. That being said, it's still incredibly fun even without mods or add-ons; the huge assortment of tools ready to be used allows for almost unlimited potential. It's almost intimidating how much you can do with this game. I don't have much playtime logged into Blockland on Steam because I played it for several years before it was greenlit, but I've played my own very generous(and unhealthy no doubt) portion of this game.

So what do you actually get? You get the ability to play as a(basically) Lego minifigure and build things. Or you can shoot things. Or you can program things in the packaged robust eventing system. There's an array of deep but simple mechanics that let you basically do anything. These features have been steadily piling on to Blockland over the years since its transition to retail some several years ago(about 8 or 9 I think). The creator, Eric Hartman(Badspot), has sandpapered off its rough edges and produced a fantastic package that's unrivalled in its scope. I'm a bit biased because I bought this game about 6 or 7 years ago and, for about 5 years, was completely absorbed by the game. Even then, it was crazy - it was something a 10 year old playing with Legos only dreamed about. Since then, it's come a long way.

Now for what you actually get; the history of the game isn't really important in your purchase. Blockland has all the bricks, blocks, and colors you'd expect from what's effectively a virtual unlimited Lego set. There are bricks that play music, spawn vehicles, and whatever else you need can be done with the game's event system(more on that later). Those aren't an issue - pretty much any block you can imagine is there, and if it's not, well, someone's created it and has made it available as an add-on. I'll try to steer clear from mentioning specific add-on content, though, because while they are free and only add to the game, they're not part of the core game. Regardless, the assortment of building materials you have is no issue.

You control a small blocky person. In the default mode(sandbox) you can fly around with your jet-propelled feet. The camera functions fairly well; you're either in first person or third person. Third person view's got all the weird nuances of any third person camera, with the screen becoming a mess when backed against a wall and things behind you getting in the way, but for the most part, it's great. There are generally no issues with controls when you're building, which is what really matters. If you have a numpad, building is very easy and with some practice you'll be laying brick like a trained mason. I haven't used the control scheme without the numpad, so I can't speak for it. The options are great and have everything you'd expect a modern PC title to have - borderless windowed, windowed, resolutions, sound options, a huge array of graphical options; it's all there.

The multiplayer is one of the greatest parts of the game. The netcode is fantastic, and I can count the times I've seen the master server down with my fingers. Whatever add-ons the host of the server you're joining has that you don't will be downloaded partially - only what's needed to play on the server. Server administration is tiered - there are admins, super admins, and the host. The server host can change around their privileges. Hosting can be done with UPNP and direct IP connection is available, though it's usually easier to just join through the server browser. LAN is possible and is great fun. Blockland certainly handles multiplayer better than many AAA multi-million dollar titles I've played.

You can play with your friends on a passworded server or play on someone else's public server. Generally, people host when either they've created something they want people to experience or they just want to hang out. Your mileage with the community may vary. If you find a group of people that are fun to play with, stick with them. There are atrociously toxic people here like with any anonymous multiplayer game. In multiplayer, to build on or otherwise modify others' bricks, you need to ask for their trust" - this can be given in two tiers: build and full trust. This is specific to each individual player. With build trust
date: you can only build on others' bricks; with full trust
hoursPlayed: paint
voteText: and event their bricks. While this is a fantastic way of keeping uncreative toxic players at bay
helpfulPercent: the really nasty ones will simply build around your bricks and make them inaccessible. This is easily preventable

column32: make sure your friends play this game with you and make something together.\n\nIf you like Legos and sandbox games you will like this game. This game can be a solid first person shooter or it can be a more compelling virtual Lego designer. At such a low price point
column33: it's a steal - you're getting much more in the package than you would with a standard sandbox game.\n\nTL;DR: Blockland is a great and unique sandbox building game. If you want to make something with your friends

reviewText: This game is disliked for one reason: because it is compared to Minecraft and Roblox, two very popular building games. Now, comparing this game to Minecraft is like comparing cows to pigs. It really doesn't make sense except for them being in the same category of game genres. I can see how you would compare this game to Roblox, but even then there are a LOT of differences. Roblox might be better in a way that you can have groups, dress easily, and what you can do on Roblox is limitless. But, Blockland is also limitless. One of the good parts about Blockland, is that it was entirely built by the community and everybody who has it has loved it. Yeah, it will continue having updates, but those updates won't change how fun Blockland is and it's style of gameplay. Hell, who cares if Blockland doesn't have groups, you can make your own that is based on Roleplaying, military, and so on. The skin designer is really easy to use and you can make some awesome decals for your shirt, pants, head, and everywhere. I recommend Blockland to anyone at the price it is at, because in my opinion, it is one hell of a game.

reviewText:
If Garry's Mod is the God of sandbox games, Blockland is the Messiah.
Blockland is a game I have logged days, weeks, and months into.
Needless to say, I was excited when it got on Steam.
Think of this game as Garry's Mod, but with legos. That's the best way to describe it.
All the maps are built piece-by-piece and the graphics are beautiful if you can run full shaders.
10/10; I recommend this game to anyone and everyone.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've played Blockland ever since V15, and I'd loved it every single minute. Sure I had some times where things didn't go well for me playing this game, but I was always able to pull through my problems in the game. I loved every single bit of detail coming from maps (back in V20 and below), shaders and shadows, and every single mod that was created from global Blockland players from around the world. I've made great friends, and introduced friends to this game, they loved it very much as well. Also thanks to this game, I went from not only just a player of this game, I went to a person who's really addicted to this game, and can't stop playing. I also finally learned how to make mods in certain categories too! Everyone loves the mods that i've made too.

Badspot, you've done a very well done on making and progressing this game to satisfaction! Congratulations, and I absoulutely recommend this game to all those people who have creative, fun, and imaginitive minds.

~NightHawk (BL_ID 22670)

reviewText:
This is my favorite game, as you could probably tell from how many hours I've played it.

Coupled with however long I played it before it was on Steam, basically, I'd say about 1100 hours of gameplay overall for me.

It's not a Minecraft ripoff (it's older than it, for one) and it's well-made, if often slow to update. The users tend to fill in for Badspot, the creator, by making addons and gamemodes and the like for everyone, usually on the official forums (Google is your friend.) You'll have lots of fun with it when you finish learning how to play, I guarantee it.

So, yeah. Play it.

reviewText:
First impressions after around 1 hour of gameplay:

- The sound effects are awful. Either too low, or so loud that it gets completely distorted.
- There is no music.
- Most of the time, the game is silent. When it is not silent, there is some explosion or some loud sound.
- The graphics don't look good. Specifically, the lighting effects and the particles look awful.
- Building blocks is not as fun because it requires both clicking and using the keyboard numpad. Minecraft got it right, putting blocks in Minecraft is fun and intuitive. Putting blocks in Blockland is not.
- The physics engine is weird and bad. I started up a new single-player kart racing game, drove for a few seconds, and accidentally hit a wall. The next second I was flying across the map.
- Multiplayer kart racing is not fun. At one moment I'm driving, at the next moment I'm flying across the map because someone hit me.
- Due to poor car handling, I have not managed to finish any kart racing. Neither in single-player, nor in multiplayer.
- I don't know if it is triple-buffering or something else, but I feel there is some input lag in the game.
- It has an achievement called Gay Pirate". I guess the author thought it would have been funny
date: but it is not. In fact
hoursPlayed: and some people might view it as offensive.\n\nAfter 1 hour of gameplay
voteText: I'm wondering why I bought this game. Well
helpfulPercent:
it was because it cost me 2 dollars. But now I wonder if I will ever play it again.

Then I come back to Steam Community and look at the developer response to some reviews. I'm really starting to regret buying this game.


Note: Using keyboard to place blocks can be very handy sometimes. However

as it means I need to move my hand away from WASD or from the mouse. Not fun.

Note 2: At least the game has a borderless mode (besides the windowed mode and fullscreen mode).

Note 3: The entire game has less than 100MB when installed.


Bottom line: I had more fun exploring worlds of Second Life

reviewText:
If you enjoy playing with lego's, this is certainly a game for you

Blockland is an non-linear lego-esque sandbox game with no goals or objectives. Instead, you start in an empty world with only your imagination. Players use bricks to construct anything they desire. Houses, castles, spaceships, anything you can think of. The only real limit is the brickcount, which i believe is around 1,000,000 bricks at once. Unless you're some hardcore extreme builder, you'll never hit this limit and you'll be free to build anything you want without worrying about running out of bricks(a common problem found with real life legos).

If you don't like building alone, it's very easy to set up a server and have friends join the fun. You could even enter a public freebuild server and hangout there.Building not you're style? That's alright, this game has multiple gamemodes aka multiple ways of playing the game. Challenge some friends to a kart race, or join a deathmatch server and show off your mad MLG no-scoping skills. Team up with other players to defeat a powerful boss. Escape from prison while avoiding police brutality. Enter a city rp, empires rp, slave rp,or, everyone's favorite roleplay, the family rp. If none of that sounds interesting, you could always try to make your own gamemode and contribute to the community.

Speaking of communtity content, the blockland forums is filled with countless amounts of add ons and new content to spice up your game. Download some new weapons, get a new car, fly a stunt plane. If you're a builder, there's tons of custom bricks and tools to make building easier and more fun.

A lot of reviews here seem to warn you about the game's community to some extent. I'll be honest, there are some pretty bad people in the game, particlularly on the forums. However there are lots of cool people aswell to meet in game and on the forums, and that's not so bad.

THE VERDICT:

I spent $20 on this game before it's steam release, and probably have 500 hours on that version. Now it's only $10, so it's even more worth it. And when it goes on sale, you should have no reason not to buy this wonderful game.

So, why are you reading this review and not buying/playing this game? Get it now, you won't regret it.
voteText: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is marked as a negative for only a few reasons of that of which I'm going to explain. First off, I saw this game around its older and more golden years. I saw the mods, the weapons, the missions, the GUI features and the many things that the community were throwing in and everyone was loving it! I wanted Blockland. Badly. Unfortunately, I could not get it until its Steam release. But only now as I buy this, I find out that RTB is closing down and maps have been removed. This was a huge disappointment to me and those who wanted to play alone at their free will and explore and do missions that people would create. Now, don't get me wrong. This game is awesome and a ton of fun. But its strongest hole is the bad timing of things I wanted to try like everyone else around its golden age. Steam, I can only pray and hope that you will return a better community that are worthy to make the perfect addons. Again, this is much like the same issue Garry's mod had. When I saw Gmod, it looked amazing and fantastic. I played Gmod 12 and loved it all. That was when at the very cut second Gmod 13 was released and I lost that feature. Blockland....Please don't fail like Gmod did. Just do what everyone else wants. Addons and maps again. That is all I want. Other then that, this game is worth getting if you love to have a lot of freedom. But if you are one who has seen Blockland in its older ages before the steam release, you are likely better off waiting but if you want, its likely worth it to buy this anyways for the simple fact of its fun little multiplayer servers.

reviewText:
I cannot recommend this game. Before I start this off, I'd like to address the 1,000 hours thing. Most of my hours are from either from me leaving the game open for my friends (partially due to the fact that blockland on steam has no dedicated support, and lacking a client made me deal with doing this for a bit), dealing with my friends playing this game, or actually enjoying 1-2 gamemodes that are put out on the game that are pretty much non existent now. I have a love hate relationship with this game, you can make something done so well, working through the games pretty dated limitations, to be utterly destroyed by the community in any way possible, because if one problem is apparent, then everyone will try to exploit and break the system you've created. I mean sure that can go for everything, right? Well not like how the community treats it. You're the bad guy if the system is partially flawed, not the people actively trying to break your system. I have been on the fence of making this review for a good 6 months or so, mostly due to how I feel about the game and the community as said from above.

Oh, I know you! You're that jerk on the forum who hosted that one server!
I don't think I want to host it ever again with how the community lashed out at me, it doesn't matter if I'm the victim at this point, here's my reasoning for why I say this: If you look at the previous works with my friends, I'm not involved, I'm not claiming to make everything, I'm trying to stay away from the spotlight because I outright don't deserve it. That's why I'm not the poster for these things, I'm not handling hosting an the event, and I'm not in charge of most of what's happening. I'm not in charge of any of this ♥♥♥♥ other than posting updates (which I didn't even do entirely), the formatting for threads, and music for our events. I don't want to pin the blame on others, because they don't deserve it, but this was outrageous. Now, during the event one of our events broke, spamming music. You know what we had to do? Restart the server. Oh, it's a tragedy, right? How dare we restart the server because something I HAD NO CONTROL OVER, broke. You know what happens then? a good 50+ people start collectively ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on me when again, I HAD NO CONTROL OVER IT. I had blame pinned on me for no reason, and the community is downright ignorant.

Oh, but you act like a prick!!
I don't want to take part in the community for the most part anymore, if I ever go on the game again it's because of my friends motives, and anything I do towards the community I do if I really feel like it's needed. I'm not saying my actions back in the past are justified because I hate the image I made for myself, but if nobody is willing to give me even a chance to act like a competent person then why even try? If I come back under a different name, people will find who I am and continue ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on me for something I did. It's not even worth my time, either. I don't want to deal with a community that actively attacks people in and outside of the community if they have a disability, I don't want associate with a community that acts this awful towards people, it's petty. I understand  I haven't been the best person around in the community, but even if I decided to change, nobody would give a ♥♥♥♥. It's easier to act like a ♥♥♥♥ back unprovoked and act ignorant because that would get someone banned faster.

What do you mean 1-2 gamemodes you've enjoyed? Wouldn't you recommend the game for that?
I have 1,000 hours on this game, I've played a majority the game has to offer, and I'm not going to be the generic the game isn't fun anymore" type of person. You have to actively sift through the ♥♥♥♥ on the master list to find games that are actually enjoyable

reviewText:
This game is infinite fun. Not only can you easily just access the server list and join the multiple servers during the summer with alot of players (Filipe1020 a former blockland user pointed out that once there were 1800 players online in total), You can also access alot of fun servers during the school year such has Prison Escape.

The only people who make negative reviews for this game are people who are known idiots and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to the game and are on the perma ban list like Kalphiter, and multiple other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who are just jealous that they cant go about a normal Blockland life on the forums or the game etc anymore because of what they have done in the past.

Do not listen to the negative reviews and play the game!

For those also wondering about the models n stuff in the trailer, its called Addons.  You can easily install addons by going on the forums and checking the Add-Ons section everyday, for those who want an easy chat system in game please download oRBs.

Now excuse me but I want to play my most favorite game in the universe and my whole life that beat Garry's Mod, Blockland.

I also have a recurring history of this game since its prototype in 2004. The maps you may see in other trailers are actually outdated ones from before v21 which removed the maps but replaced the game with awesome shadows and shaders.

For those who couldn't read my huge wall of text, I just want to point out the fact you should just shut up and click the Add to Cart button. The fun is only a 10 dollar bill away!

reviewText:
Blockland is a really good game. Badspot made something awesome here. I can start the game up and go on a server and have fun instantly. No matter the gamemode. Racing in carts is fun. Mining for hours just to get a good pickaxe is fun. Sniping other players is fun. The entire game is fun, heck, building pixel art of Mario and putting the fire emitters on it is cool to see.

The whole concept of the game is really awesome. It's easy to mod, it's easy to have fun, and it's not expensive. I got the game for $2.49 while it was on sale and I wish I would have bought it for it's full price. Building in an online enviroment has never given me as much freedom as this game does. Think building with LEGO's online.

The community here is outstanding. They practically make the game. There's tons of mods, tons of minigames, an acceptable amount of servers with nice, friendly people. Well, usually the people are friendly. There are some badmins out there and just plain rude people out there but it's the internet so thats not very surprising.

The game isn't updated much anymore though, but oh well. What we have here is a cool little game you can have hours of fun on. Although it isn't as popular as it was before, Blockland stands out to me as one the funniest times I've had playing a game with friends and I'd recommend it to anyone who loves building stuff and letting their imagination flow.

reviewText:
I have been playing this game since version 8--when there were only about 3000 players. I've loved this game and it's been basically the backbone of my internet career. You can literally do anything you want here--there are City RPGs, Freebuilds, Deathmatches, Mini Empires...all sorts of things. This is the LEGO game there never was. A multitude of mods make the game have the capability to host many different types of game modes that only need your brain to think up something good--there are even servers out there that you play on these floating platforms in the sky with only a grappling hook and a knife.

The game used to have all sorts of terrain and buildings that you could play in, but with v28 those have been (sadly) removed. They were replaced with shaders which can really make the game look pretty, but if your computer can't handle them (most can handle them on medium at least), it's kind of a moot point.

If you like playing building games with friends and want to get your creative juices flowing, get this game.

reviewText:
I have had Blockland for the pat 5 years since v12. People will tell you the problem with this is the building system and truthfully you just need to get use to numb pad. Its the 3rd part in learning how to plant bricks in the tutorial where you put it in the small hole (that's what she said hehe) but really mastering numb pad is key to building and in-fact, makes it easier than most games since if you miss you can just press a button to move it in place. I am a builder and I am proud. I highly suggest you buy this game since its the game that keeps on giving. I have played for 5 years and I shall go another 5.

P.S. if you feel like a reason not to get this game is the community remember the steam community will become the majority so all problems found in it will practically cease to exist.

P.S.S. I request you call the community blockheads since blocklanders sounds dumb IMO.

reviewText: Here's a game that's worth a look at. It says I don't have that long of a playtime but I just connected this game to Steam not too long ago. This game isn't that popular sadly but it is a ton of fun and I definitely recommend it without a doubt.\n\n10/10

reviewText: Great game, I loved playing it back in the day with maps and the great service known as RTB. However is recent years Badspot decided to remove the maps in exchange for enhance graphics and shaders. Despite the fact that I loved map, especially bedroom, it was a welcome change for me as I could now build on an unlimited scale. And, I've noticed some people say that there is stuff like a vehicle, bot, and a brick limit. Now this is mostly seen on the demo version of the game and these limits in the full version can be changed in the server settings before you start your server. Anyways, probably one of the best sandbox games I've ever seen, and I would love to see its community grow greatly. Who knows, maybe in years to come we might get RTB and maps added back into the game. Keep building and have fun!

reviewText:
Blockland is a really good game. Badspot made something awesome here. I can start the game up and go on a server and have fun instantly. No matter the gamemode. Racing in carts is fun. Mining for hours just to get a good pickaxe is fun. Sniping other players is fun. The entire game is fun, heck, building pixel art of Mario and putting the fire emitters on it is cool to see.

The whole concept of the game is really awesome. It's easy to mod, it's easy to have fun, and it's not expensive. I got the game for $2.49 while it was on sale and I wish I would have bought it for it's full price. Building in an online enviroment has never given me as much freedom as this game does. Think building with LEGO's online.

The community here is outstanding. They practically make the game. There's tons of mods, tons of minigames, an acceptable amount of servers with nice, friendly people. Well, usually the people are friendly. There are some badmins out there and just plain rude people out there but it's the internet so thats not very surprising.

The game isn't updated much anymore though, but oh well. What we have here is a cool little game you can have hours of fun on. Although it isn't as popular as it was before, Blockland stands out to me as one the funniest times I've had playing a game with friends and I'd recommend it to anyone who loves building stuff and letting their imagination flow.

reviewText:
I have been playing this game since version 8--when there were only about 3000 players. I've loved this game and it's been basically the backbone of my internet career. You can literally do anything you want here--there are City RPGs, Freebuilds, Deathmatches, Mini Empires...all sorts of things. This is the LEGO game there never was. A multitude of mods make the game have the capability to host many different types of game modes that only need your brain to think up something good--there are even servers out there that you play on these floating platforms in the sky with only a grappling hook and a knife.

The game used to have all sorts of terrain and buildings that you could play in, but with v28 those have been (sadly) removed. They were replaced with shaders which can really make the game look pretty, but if your computer can't handle them (most can handle them on medium at least), it's kind of a moot point.

If you like playing building games with friends and want to get your creative juices flowing, get this game.

reviewText:
I have been playing this game since 2008.
This game has sincerely changed my life since the first day I played it, and I literally have not stopped playing it ever since. First of all, there is a rival between this game, minecraft, and roblox, mostly about what came first, and what is worse or better. Well, Minecraft, came out in 2009, and is pretty bland. Roblox, the game everyone hates, came out in around 2006? Blockland started developing in 2005, and was released around 2007. And this game is still amazing. Now the community has gotten a bit bad after Steam kicked in, but its still the same game. V21 has changed it all. People say they hate it, but everyone wanted it. You all got what was coming. The game was great before shaders, and its even better. Its unfortunate they couldn't keep maps (because they glitched with shaders), so the first trailer they made is false advertising. But their updated one shows its true glory. Sure, there is no environment, no terrain, no maps. But remember.

This is a game where you build stuff.

reviewText: I've been playing this game regularly for seven years, and for a couple years before that I played this game at my friend's house, before Minecraft" was conceived.\n\nHonestly
date: people leaving negative reviews because "the community sucks" probably acted like an arrogant turd and got treated like one. This game has a great community which manages to produce great projects and creations regularly
recommended: despite the small player base. Sure there's trolls
hoursPlayed: but they only affect you if you let them
voteText: you know?\n\nThere's a small learning curve to start building
helpfulPercent: but if you've played with LEGO bricks in your life you'll know what to do once you get the controls down. Once you get a hang of building
votesHelpful: you will discover that eventing (using the wrench tool) opens up a whole new level of gameplay and really seperates this game from other LEGO-esque building games.\n\nYou can also spice up your game with amazing mods that are available on the Blockland Forums. I highly recommend checking that out if you play Blockland
votesTotal: seriously.\n\nIf you're not a creator
votesFunny: you can still enjoy other people's games that they create within Blockland. I personally enjoy adventure servers and deathmatches
commentsCount:
but there's many of other gamemodes to enjoy.

PROS:
Good Building Mechanics
Graphics
Eventing
Weapons
Environmental Controls
Mods allow for customization
Gamemodes
Game has aged well

CONS:
Steep learning curve
Vehicles are wonky
There's not a lot of players
Sometimes things get dramatic in the community

OVERALL: 9/10
